review: My 1st time in New York and my friends, family & I decided to stay at AC. When we arrived to our surprise the room was ready & we were able to check-in. The front desk staff were mediocre gave us 1 key for 3 people & sent us on our way. The room was very clean I noticed that right away but the room was on the small side but very modern. Two of the workers were extremely nice. There was a young women at the reception desk she had glasses & blond hair I didn't catch her name, she always smiled and waved when ever we came in & out the hotel. I meet one of the maintenance men Shakeem I asked him where could I go to get ice and he told me the 3rd floor and he also told me all the amenities the hotel offers. He showed me the fabulous lounge on the 2nd floor and told me where the gym was located. I was stunned I thought I would‚Äôve gotten told these things as I was checking in. Anytime I saw him he asked if we were ok & did we need anything. He even showed me on my map all the places I needed to go. Overall the location was great, awesome views from the room! Bar had good drinks but very dull atmosphere. Didn‚Äôt get to taste the food but it‚Äôs good you do offer breakfast. I love the fact that you need your room key to enter the building at night. I can see myself staying here again. I do appreciate the customer service I received from Shakeem & the young lady at the reception.
response: Dear Alisunshine20,Welcome to New York City and thank you for choosing us to be your hotel to experience the city for the first time. Our goal is to exceed our guests' expectations so I regret that you found us to be lacking in a couple of aspects of your stay. We appreciate you recognizing our strengths while providing us with some areas of opportunity. I hope we have the chance to better serve you on a future visit.Sincerely,Craig KeppleGeneral Manager

review: I feel as if I've been scammed and cheated on my booking rates. I've tried for (2) months to get this resolved, they've had me like a ping pong ball going back n forth spending hours of my day on the phone speaking to and emailing different reps both onsite Hotel and Marriot customer service line. The end result, I was never refunded what I was overcharged much less no one had the courtesy of getting back after all my attempts to reach out and get some answers. A million Hotels to choose from in NYC and based on my AAA membership discount I chose this Hotel, the rates offered were $205 night and after applying my membership the rates went down to $143 night. Total cost inclusive of 3 nights, taxes & fees $505.31. (Cant beat those rates thus I booked immediately)To my surprise when I checked out, the next day what I was charged on my bank card was $794.98! ($289.67 over rates offered) When I called the Hotel directly I was told "We're sorry as we are unable to apply the AAA discount now that you have checked out of our Hotel"SERIOUSLY? They did NOT honor it to begin with and now telling me they cannot correct their mistake?!Mind you the DAILY CONSTRUCTION noise level at all hours. NEVER AGAIN AND WILL NEVER RECOMMEND THIS HOTEL-

hotel: AC Hotel by Marriott Boston Cleveland Circle
review: At first we were excited that this new hotel was opening up just a few blocks from where our grandsons and family live on Beacon Street... how convenient! Then we arrived this week for our first overnight stay. First and foremost, you need to know that the south side of the hotel is right next to the T. So, all the even numbered rooms are "track-side". Also, the lower the number, the closer to the tracks the room will be. So, we were given room 202, the closest to the T tracks you can get. The T runs until about midnight, then starts again around 5:30 AM, and once it gets started, there are many, many trains. For $300/night, guests deserve better!The second important thing visitors should be aware of in advance is the $40/night valet charge for parking. There is virtually no alternative to park elsewhere in the area since most parking spots are for residents. There are a few overnight meters where you can park from 8PM to 8AM, but the only ones I know are several blocks away on Beacon Street, so you need to wait to park your car after 8:00PM and then be sure to get back to the spot to take your car out the next morning before 8:00.These two major issue aside, the hotel is new and clean, and the rooms are a nice size with a roomy bath (at least in our room). Each room has a self contained HVAC unit that is a bit on the noisy side. So, if you want to get to sleep in peace, set the thermostat low before bed, then bump it back up to the temperature you want overnight as you climb into bed. That way you may be able to fall asleep without having to hear the system come on and go off. The room comes with breakfast, but we were anxious to leave and only took away coffee. Remember.... odd numbered rooms are quieter!!!
response: Dear GuestThank you for the rating and the comments regarding your recent stay at our property in Cleveland Circle.We appreciate all the specific input and though we can't change the location we may be able to adjust the AC units to be more quiet. Your input is truly appeciated.Thank you for taking the time to comment as feedback is key and we hope to see again very soon at any of our Colwen Group Properties.Sincerely,The Customer Service TeamColwen Hotel Group
triptype: Trip type: Traveled as a couple

review: I stayed at this hotel for 3 nights while and chose it for it's location to Boston College. The rooms were a bit too modern for me (no carpets, minimal lighting, not much furniture to sit on) but they were very clean and spacious. However, the price we paid was high, given that it is very noisy room. The hotel is directly across the street from a D line T stop and the end of the line C. So we hear squeaky subways constantly, late hours of the night while trying to fall asleep and early hours of morning. Maybe they run all night, I don't know.Also there is no place to walk around. If you want the location to hop right on the T, then it's good, otherwise, pass for a hotel with a better and quieter location.Also felt with the $40 parking added to the room it was a bit pricy total. No real lobby or common area and no good furniture in the rooms (too minimal and modern to be comfortable after a long day)

review: Our group chose this hotel for it's location which turned out to be the only thing we liked. We booked 4 rooms for 2 nights each. The first night one person in our group talked to management concerning the price of the room. She gave him a discount and told him to not tell the other people in the group because she would not give anyone else in the group a discount. The group found out the evening of the second night. When I spoke to the manager, Allie, about the price it was apparent that she had made up her mind to not work with the group. She told me that she had told the one Male member of our group of 8 not to tell he had gotten a discount because she wouldn't be giving a discount to anyone else. We booked as a group, we should have all paid the same amount. I also brought up that the price was $70 cheaper online though travel sites per night. So not only did she favor one out of the four rooms, she also made it apparent that no one should ever book through the hotel, instead book through a travel site. Very poor business model to make people that book through the hotel and book ahead of time pay more than someone who books online where another company takes a cut of what the customer pays. The manager, Allie, told us that we should have cancelled our reservation and booked through the travel site if we wanted a better price. Horrible customer service. Smaller issues being no breakfast included for almost $260 a night, smelly hallways, stingy on the complementary items in the room (one bottle of water for a room with double beds- when asked for another they offered to sell me one), and not good service at the bar in the lobby. The dangerous part is the elevators. One of the members of our grouo was trying to hold the elevator door for another and the doors did not want to stay open. While she was standing in the way of one side of the door, it started making a beeping noise and began closing, pushing her towards the other side of the closing door, luckily she was able to stay on her feet and dive out before the doors closed on her. Extremely dangerous! What if she would have fallen and been unable to get out of the way in time?? Overall, do not book here! Go literally next door to Element or up the street to the Westin...anywhere else!
response: Dear happyhourhopper....I am sorry that your experience at our hotel proved so difficult. As it relates to the questions regarding rate, we adhere to an industry leading best available rate program by booking direct with our hotel website. That does not mean that prices do not fluctuate over time for all hotels. If a leader decided to make an adjustment in good faith for a guest, this does not influence pricing on additional rooms, but I am happy to connect with you personally to discuss further at Christy.loy@starwoodhotels.com. Thank you also for making us aware of your concern regarding the elevators during your recent visit. The elevators are designed to respond to the door hold button open button for an extended period or to respond to motion. Our engineering team monitors functionality as part of their daily rounds, but I will certainly make sure they are aware. Thank you for your feedback and please feel free to reach out to me at your convenience.
responder: Response from Christy_Aloft, General Manager at Aloft Boston Seaport District

review: We did not enjoy our two night stay. The check-in desk is a circular island close to the entrance doors to a cavernous lobby. Upon arrival there was a queue of guests waiting to check in (only two clerks on duty). This queue impeded entry to and exit from the hotel. Upon checking in we were advised there would be no water available the following morning from 09:00 until noon as there had been a mains burst and City Water were undertaking repairs. Though this was obviously not the fault of the hotel, the clerk kindly offered us two complimentary drinks at the bar. (Though this did not eventuate as he couldn't find any vouchers).The bar is open to the very noisy lobby. I've seen better in an airport departure hall. The 'restaurant' was in another corner of the lobby and comprised a hot drink vending machine, fridges with frozen ready meals, a microwave, shelves with canned drinks and packets of snacks. I've seen better in a backpackers.The bedroom was nicely decorated, spacious and had a king size bed. Bathroom and shower perfectly adequate. Fridge and in room safe available. Good number of power points for recharging your electronic devices. The aircon unit was almost of industrial size - emitting a strong blast of air, very noisy and hard to regulate.When my wife tried to make coffee in the coffee maker, upon pouring water into the reservoir it turned milky (I guess the previous guests had poured milk into the reservoir to make a latte). Anyway, she refused to use the machine, not knowing what substance was in the reservoir. We rang room service and they supplied a replacement machine.The hotel is situated in an industrial desert, overlooking truck yards and shipping container storage. (See attached view from the bedroom). Boston Seaport is undergoing rapid development - I'm sure the area will be vibrant in about 15 years. The nearest bar is adjacent to The Westin about 10 mins walk down deserted D Street. The nearest restaurant is a small counter-top eatery about 5 mins down D Street.
response: Dear Gaijin-Tanuki‚Ä¶thank you for taking the time to share your experience with us. I am sorry for the area of concern you raised, especially for the delay at check-in and the frustration with the water outage situation as well as the coffee maker. We will be sure to address these issues with our team.Also, thank you for highlighting some of the positive features of our rooms. I want to take a moment to share some details about upcoming changes that will make the hotel that much more attractive for a return visit. This week a full-service restaurant will open in our adjacent retail space that will feature new American cuisine and a craft cocktail list. We are installing an arborvitae hedge to screen the patio from the lot under development behind us and are also pleased to partner with the Lawn on D directly across the street in offering our guests one of the most innovative outdoor spaces in Boston. Things are always changing here in the Seaport and I do hope you will consider giving us another try in the future. Again, thank you again for your feedback, I truly appreciate it.

review: When selecting the hotel, the property's web site made the location sound as if it was in the center of activity. In reality, it is located in a quiet, industrial part of Boston near the convention center. There are very few restaurants with a short walk and no shops and services. The breakfast was not great, so it is worth going elsewhere. The staff were uniformly friendly and helpful and the rooms were large and comfortable. For a property that is a little more than a year old, however, the air conditioning units were noisy and hard to control, so I ended up shutting it off most of the time. The first room I was given had exposed pipes with a loud drip, so I requested and was given a different room. If you are using the convention center, it is not a bad choice. If you prefer a central, convenient area, this is not the place.

review: Stood here while visiting Columbia University. Hotel looks nice on the outside. My room was a different story. It was pretty disgusting! The cleaning was not done properly for who knows how long. I first noticed the inside of the shower door had marks when it fogged up -- male splatter marks. I'm a female and I def know that was not from me! They had complimentary body wash (white) and shampoo in the shower in pumps attached to the wall. All I can think about was the body wash probably has some other junk mixed in. UGH! Ok...then I was in bed and kept thinking about the gross shower and if I should call to change rooms because I then noticed male splatter marks ALL OVER THE WALLS!!!! I mean I don't know the housekeeping protocol, but wiping down walls should be done. I do admit if you were busy and didn't really look or pay attention you wouldn't notice. But once I saw one mark, I saw them ALL. Whoever was in that room had a hay day. I just wished it was cleaned up!!! During check in, lady was extremely nice to people ahead of me -- giving them coupons and complimentary breakfast coupons. Once I got to her, I did not receive any coupons or complimentary anything! And I had to wait twice as long because she was talking too much and apologizing for the wait to the other people! Oh Well...Location to Columbia is OK and within walking distance. It is uphill so be prepared for a trek! NYPD is close and there is a nice park nearby. Seemed safe, I was able to walk everywhere day and night. Just please train your cleaning staff to clean and disinfect the insides of the showers from top to bottom!!! And keep an eye on the walls!

hotel: Best Western Plus Hobby Airport Inn & Suites
review: On October 19, 2018, I flew into Houston from Chicago intending to catch another plane out to Oklahoma City, as luck would have it, the Chicago flight was delayed and I missed the connecting flight. I was also without my suitcase as it had been checked to go on to OK City. I called the hotel, and having already been warned by my daughter that they might not accept my debit card with my husband's name on it, I explained this to the clerk answering the phone. She stated no problem and I'll send a shuttle over, please go to area 14 pick up. I was relieved to arrive as I had been suffering from vertigo and had hurt my knee trying to race through the airport. Patricia was the desk clerk, when I gave her the debit card, she told me I could not check in because my husband wasn't present. I called my husband and he phoned corporate where we have a credit card on file as we are members of the reward program. Corporate called the desk and spoke to Patricia indicating that she should accept me, she told them no it wasn't the policy of the hotel. My plane landed at 8:oo pm and I stood there offering cash to no avail, after three calls from corporate and starting to call my other business friends to tell them to avoid this hotel, Patricia finally said she would accept cash....originally she had quoted me $78 but now it was $98 plus $100 deposit. I paid it. She knew I did not even have my suitcase with me, but she never even offered a complimentary toothbrush. After going to my room at 10:54pm, I grabbed my coin purse and headed back down to see if I could buy one. When I stepped outside my door, I could hear Patricia directly below me complaining about me to other employees. There were none for sale in the sundries area so I returned to the desk and asked another young lady for a toothbrush and she gave me one. I returned to my room and ordered Dominos pizza delivery, and finally got to eat supper at midnight! This is not the Texas hospitality that I knew as a child growing up in the state! The room was clean and comfortable, but the hospitality was totally lacking! The next morning I left at 7 am, and was not given a receipt for my stay. I did not eat the breakfast offered because I felt so very unwelcome. Never again!!!
response: Dear guest,I definitely understand that you were already in distress you due your flight being cancelled. I also agree with you that you felt my staff had to have more compassion for you in the situation you were in. However, Patricia, did follow all policies in place to insure our credit card member safety and security are in place since there was no way of really knowing who was the card holder since he was not present at the time. I am truly sorry that you felt that we were uninviting to you during your short stay here with us. As always we would love to have you stay with us.Till then please be safe.Flo Vega
responder: Response from Best Western Pl... H, General Manager at Best Western Plus Hobby Airport Inn & Suites

review: We stayed here two separate nights on this trip. AAA has them rated 3 stars which is about right in our opinion. Good pricing with discount compared to some others nearby.Pros - Staff friendly. Great free breakfast with scrambled eggs and waffles. New renovations. Excellent fitness room. Very close to Hobby airport and car rentals. Note: don't use Hertz, poor experience there with staff, pricing, poor customer processes/flow, and trying to charge us for existing damage. We normally use Enterprise and will not use Hertz again. We took a drive east to Galveston Bay in LaPorte where there was a nice beach and pier since we had a few hours of free time.Cons - Our first night, the first room we were assigned 124 had a strong musty damp smell that didn't go away even after two hours with windows open and AC on while we were at dinner. They readily moved us to a 2nd floor suite which smelled much better. That room was very nice but was not quite done with reno work. Our second night's stay there we were given room 216 which had the same smell but not quite as strong. We aired it out while at dinner which helped too. Could not find the source of the smell. Reno- it's obvious they have tried to do a great job with the work and upgrades. Some of the finish work is not done well so it is not going to wear well and already seeing problems, like paint coming off the bathroom door. There are no restaurants in walking distance. We had to drive quite a ways to find something that was decent.Recommendation - if you are looking for value and don't mind the possibility of what we experienced it's not a bad place. The smell was really the only big issue for us.
response: Dear Guest,Thank You for taking the time to review our hotel and pointing out ways we can improve. I apologize for what you experienced during your recent stay at our hotel and appreciate it that you brought it to our attentions. We will readily work to fix the issue and hope you will give us another chance to provide excellence service.Thank You,Manager

review: A friend and I were visiting Universal Studios for a day and had to find a hotel to stay at for one night before flying out. Besides upscale hotels that were out of our price range, the Blvd Hotel and Spa was the least expensive (if you call $250/night less expensive) than the Sheraton and others. We expected a lot more for what we paid. The walls were paper thin and we were able to hear long-winded conversations both next door and down the hall. And the parking was terrible. It was the type of parking where you have to pull your card forward in a 2-car bumper to bumper parking space and hope that when you leave the car in back of you is gone. They said that if your car was the outside car, that you're supposed to leave your car keys with the staff so they can move the other car so you can leave. In theory that may work, but on the day we left, there were 2 young ladies waiting to leave and no one knew whose car was in back of them. Thankfully, we found one of only a couple of one car only spaces and didn't have any problem. And on top of that, parking was $20 per night. Won't be staying there again!
response: Hi Pennie_Wilhelm,We appreciate you taking the time to write a review about your recent stay with us. Thank you for your honest review. review: First room had only a shower and was grotty, so asked if I could move to a room with a tub. They very kindly moved me. After I unpacked, I thought I would have a nice bath, I noticed a horrible musty smell in the bathroom. I asked to be moved into a decent room and they did. Room 205. It wasn't as run down as the other two rooms. Not sure why the hotel is called a spa hotel as there isn't one. I was looking forward to using the facilities. It was possible to have someone come to the room, but I didn't want to do that. Its a very basic hotel, no safe. I pulled the plug on the refrigerator as it was loud every now and then. The coffee is good and the staff are friendly.

review: We are locals who had to be out of the house for a few days during renovations in November. This hotel was the only one in the area with an indoor pool - kids wanted to swim, but November is too cold for us to swim outdoors! The pool was perfect - small, but heated like a big bathtub. The location was very close to Universal Studios, which was convenient. The hotel is modern and trendy - many young people staying here. The bar/lounge downstairs had happy hour which was popular. Overall it was a fine experience, but some cons especially with the pool - the main reason we chose this hotel. The pool hours were incorrectly listed in the printed materials (other guests told us was wrong on the web as well) as closing at 7:00 PM - glad we asked for clarification and were told 10:00 PM - otherwise we would have assumed we missed swim hours and wouldn't have tried to swim on a couple of evenings. The pool door was locked 3 of the 4 times we tried, and no access with room key. Had to walk all the way back to the lobby (through the chilly parking garage) to get someone to open the door. Towels not always stocked poolside. And the pool area was pretty drab and depressing - painted grey like the parking garage, with some broken windows. Could use some blue paint on the walls like in the rooms, and some better attention to this area. Final complaint was that my bill at checkout did not reflect the rate I was quoted during my reservation. Had I not asked for a final printout, and also had a printed copy of the emailed reservation, I would have been charged $50 more per night, and more tax. And I think everyone would complain about $28 per day parking fee. That stings. We would probably go back in a similar situation, but if swimming during colder weather is not a priority then there are lots of other nearby hotels I would try first.
response: Thank you for staying with us chrisfCA. We are pleased that we were able to accommodate you during your home renovations, and you were able to take advantage of our small heated indoor pool. We appreciate your feedback about the pool hours as well as some maintenance issues that we could improve on. We hope you do give us another chance to not only meet, but exceed, your expectations.
responder: Response from BLVDHOTELSTUDIOCITY, Guest Relations Manager at Blvd Hotel & Spa

review: $31 per night parking charge with no on street or other options spoil this otherwise comfy and fairly convenient hotels location to Universal Studio's. Room is generous and easily can handle a longer term stay of a week. Separate sitting room has fridge, micro wave, sofa and a real working desk. Unfortunately, WI-FI is very spotty and we used our personal hot spot most of the time. Two TV's, one is in bedroom pod and one in sitting room make for a nice combination.Lobby has a nice bar and a 24 hour handy pre packaged sandwich shop.Eateries abound within walking distance but neighbourhood can be a bit sketchy so we drove. 101 Freeway across the street so ask for a room on the opposite side.Bathroom is large for a hotel and well thought out. Only problem is hot water in short supply. Warm is the average "hot" setting.We had a bath maintenance issue that was promptly addressed.Desk staff runs from very friendly and helpful to surly (one individual).If you are here to visit Universal a better option would be the on site Sheraton or Hilton, but for a somewhat funky experience that gets the job done BLVD is fine, but nowhere near great.

review: Just got back from NYC..first & last time that I will ever stay here! Check in staff was not very friendly.. I asked where to park my car and it was almost an imposition for me to be asking. The room was nice, but no coffee pot in it. You had to go to the fourth floor for coffee & their continental breakfast..the room had 4 tables, very tiny & extremely hot. Couldn't really move around in it with 10 other people in there. We stayed 3 days & they were suppose to pay for parking.. Right! Only one day of parking..got ripped off! Also, they have smoking rooms here & they can not guarantee you get one when you make the reservation either. You have to pay for Wi-fi..it's not free!! There are much better places to stay in NYC..that have more amenities to offer. This place was a disappointment.

review: My wife and children returned on November 27th from our overnight stay at the Broadway Plaza.My wife and I stayed in room 606. At 11:00 pm on Thanksgiving Day, we were getting ready to go to bed and I noticed that there were blood stains on both the bed comforter and bed sheet. I called the front desk to express my concern and disappointment and was told that they would care of it. Well, after an hour went by, I called the front desk again to express my deep dissatisfaction and was told that clean sheets were on their way. They arrived 10 minutes later; however, it was not their staff's intent to strip the bed and put on new sheets. They expected me to do that and look bewildered when I expressed my displeasure. So, I changed the sheets and comforter myself. When I checked out of the hotel at 11:00 am on November 27, I waited for the front desk clerk to say something. Unfortunately, she said nothing until I once again mentioned what had happened to which she said "Oh yes, I'm sorry about that." So, I will never stay at the Broadway Plaza again because their quality control is lacking, their staff training is either poor or non-existent, and they don't understand what a true apology means (It is more than saying your sorry!) It is amazing to me that an organization doing business in the hospitality sector where ever dime of the customer's spend is discretionary, doesn't understand the firs thing about service recovery. After all, any organization can excel in the customer's eyes when things go well; however, the real test of an organization is being able to recover in front of the customer when things do not go well. The Broadway Plaza failed big time!
response: We were very shocked and disappointed to see your comments as this is not the type nor level of customer service we typically offer. Obviously we dropped the ball badly. One of the hotel managers has already contacted you and apologized profusely on behalf of the hotel as well as gave a discount for this stay and a discount on your next stay. We take your comments very seriously and have already spoken to all appropriate staff members on how this should have been handled so nothing like this ever happens again. We hope you will give us another chance to redeem ourselves and stay with us again to show you our normal standard of warm and efficient customer service which obviously you did not receive. We apologize once again.
responder: Response from broadwayplaza, General Manager at Broadway Plaza Hotel

review: Stayed with my wife for 4 nights at this location. The proximity to subway lines (NQR) as well as (1) was very nice. As others have mentioned the breakfast room is small with around 3-4 tables, you will have to take items back to your room. Hotel has ice and vending only on 7th floor. Elevator went out one day during our stay however they were able to get this resolved. We never felt unsafe at any time as there is a heavy police presence every few blocks and there are police cameras everywhere. Doormen are very helpful with getting a cab if necessary. I would like to caution that you should be prepared for the street vendors if you will be walking Broadway to Time Square or the Flatiron area. These are guys that are standing around along Broadway and they are all selling some variety of handbags, watches, cologne etc. It does get annoying quickly. Lots of Bars in the area. The immediate food options are limited to room service or the Pizza place next door. You would need to go further down Broadway or 5th Avenue for other variety. There is some major construction going on in this area, the noise is minimal however.

review: We stayed here for a 3-night stay. Overall, the hotel is stylish and attractive, and its location across the street from the Broadway T station is hard to beat. We also had a very reasonable room rate. But there were several shortcomings that kept us from rating this property higher.PROS:-- Appealing contemporary design-- Easy access to public transportation-- Several good dining options in neighborhood-- Comfortable bed, spacious shower, and large-screen televisionCONS:-- The room was small, and there was no place to put any baggage (no luggage stand or rack), also no shelves or drawers (just hangers), making unpacking options very limited.-- The room had not been vacuumed prior to our check-in, nor was it vacuumed during our 3-night stay.-- The room was not serviced following our first night.-- Following our second night, the housekeeping staff removed a partial roll of toilet paper but did not replace it, and there was no spare roll, so we had to call the front desk for toilet paper. (Most hotels have toilet paper on the dispenser and at least one additional spare roll in the room.)-- Both check-in and check-out were less than efficient (although friendly).-- $50/night parking charge is steep.Other minor technical issues, like incorrectly coded key cards, a loose shower gasket seal, a loose/warped door panel covering the HVAC unit, and one of the elevators temporarily out of commission did not help.The hotel would certainly merit a rating of at least 4 were it not for these minor and easily addressed problems.
response: Dear JJ,Thank you for your review and for staying with us recently. We too would like you to have the most pleasant experience possible and we always appreciate the feedback. We're happy to hear that you enjoyed our location and you were able to walk to many of the locations you needed to visit.Regarding the shortcomings, I am very sorry to hear about the lack of housekeeping service and the less than efficient check in and check out. As we continue to train our team, we will get better at delivering the services that one would expect from a fine hotel like ours.Thank you again.

hotel: Cambria Hotel Miami Airport - Blue Lagoon
review: Booked a room as it was #17 out of 110 hotels in Miami per Trip Advisor. NO WAY!Rooms are ok, most people who work here are fine. Management, tho, clearly does not care: they 'provide' amenities (e.g. free Wi-Fi, Room Service, Breakfast buffet, etc), so the list of amenities looks good; but VERY insufficiently provided. Miami is a big place - much better options available. Specific examples:- The room cards provided upon check-in did not work, so had to go back down to check-in desk to get them fixed. The 'fixed' cards did not work so had to return back down. They couldn't activate the cards. After a few minutes of trying, they finally found some papers on their desk, which 'enlightened' them apparently that the room was not available. Asked them what the reason was, and they just ignored my question, sneering at each other.With a scowl on her face, one of the attendants studied her computer monitor for a couple of minutes and told me they had another room on the first floor. Told her I don't like first floors. After a couple of more minutes, they found a room on the 2nd floor. Check-in all in all took almost 30 minutes.- Room service menu is available in the room. But when I called them, they said I had to come downstairs to pick up the food as they don't have anybody to deliver to the rooms.- Breakfast buffet: They have several warming buffet canisters, but all empty. This is at around 7:30am on a weekday. No spoons; only fork and knife.- Wi-Fi is free, which is great. However, it kept getting disconnected, so had to log back on and on.- Morning of my checkout, they slid the statement thru under my door, like most hotels do. But the statement only showed -0- charge. So I went downstairs early morning to get a full statement, though i was not quite ready to check out yet, as I wanted to avoid a line later. The attendant told me I had to come back when I was checking out. So when I went back to check out, of course, there was a line.I must say I am now beginning to doubt the reliability of the Trip Advisor ratings. What I know for certain is I will never ever stay at a Cambria, Miami or elsewhere.
response: Dear Nekotamachan,Thank you for taking the time to fill out a review regarding your recent stay with us. Thank you again for your feedback and we hope to see you again while in Miami.

review: The Cambria is a great hotel. The location, however, makes parking a bit of a hassle if it is not on a Sunday and they charge $55 for valet parking, with no ins and outs. review: For the business traveler who doesn't want to break the bank on a hotel in downtown Chicago, the Central Look Hotel is a good option. The hotel is less than 2 blocks away from the the Jackson CTA subway station, which means a traveler can board a train at O'Hare and get off in downtown Chicago just a short walk from the hotel -- no changing trains required. The hotel also has an excellent business/work area just below the lobby that has both Macs and PC computers, coffee, juice and light munchies.As for negatives, the basic rooms at this hotel are underwhelming. The rooms are small, the beds are substandard, and the WiFi marginal at best.For those who don't care about cost, the Central Loop Hotel will likely be a disappointment. But for the budget minded business traveler this hotel is a solid choice.

review: I should have known from the price what to expect, but there were so many good reviews. Anyone rating this hotel better than 2 stars are either people with extremely low expectations or country bumpkins out in the city for the first time. It is not possible to control your room temperature according to management. It's "an old building". So while it's a lovely, cool spring evening outside, my room is about 85 degrees. Management sent me a fan to help. It's about 8" in diameter and is just swirling hot air. I was supposed to stay here two nights, but I am checking out in the AM to stay at a 'modern' building. Do not stay here unless you are indifferent to sweltering temperatures in winter (and I am guessing Arctic temperatures in summer).

Unfortunately, it turned out that it was through another platform and when I arrived they were unable to provide a lesser rate. Because of the huge cancellation fee, I stayed there. Arrived up to my room on the 4th floor which is really tiny. Window faces into a brick wall. Nothing they can do about that. No hand towels or wash clothes. Had to get them to fix drain in tub as it wasn't draining. No secondary safety lock on the doors. If you decide to stay there I'd advise a rubber doorstop. Room was clean but the hotel needs upkeep. review: Well, let's start with the good. MUCH cheaper than the $250-$300 a night wanted in downtown Seattle. Quick drive out of downtown. Fast check in and out. The front desk clerk at check in was very professional and helpful. That is about it for the good. So the bad. Parking lot is very tight. Parking in the garage is laughable if you own anything other than a very small car and the lot is not much better. The foyer is small but adequate. Hallways are dated as well as the rooms. Our room had an interesting aroma to it. Comments ranged from smells like salsa, to mildew, to just plain weird--can't identify it. Did not go away our entire stay. The room was big enough, but not clean enough. There were visible stains on the couch, chair and carpet. I am not sure the sheets had been changed on either bed, even though the beds were comfy enough. There were stains on the sheets. There was active mold growing on the caulk in the bathroom. The bathtub faucet leaked the entire time we were there and the water pressure was lacking. Breakfast was a joke. There were the standard breakfast items, except most of them were not stocked and did not see anyone restocking anything. Hot tub was ok, not busy. And to top it off, I am not sure we were staying in the best area of town. I am not familiar with north Seattle, but saw some questionable activity on the streets nearby. Would not recommend this hotel. Pay a little more in Seattle or search for something else nearby.
response: I panicked when I saw this title.Thank you for the good and the bad comments.We are in the process of several updates that should answer all of those comments, So I hope you might give us a second chance.Thanks againAndrea StricklandGuest services
responder: Response from gmwa217, GSA at Comfort Inn & Suites Seattle

Also the water pressure in the shower was extremely low and the temperature of the water was either extremely hot or cool. The location isn't good either. Think twice before staying at this hotel.

review: Arrived at the hotel on a tour bus and the room keys had not been named which caused some delay. The car park had been recently resurfaced which gave a fresh look to the exterior.The interior was however a little dated but at first glance around fit for purpose. When we went to the room which was at the rear of the hotel we were greeted with the sound of a train in close proximity to the bedroom window. To say it was noisy was an understatement and these trains run at least every 30 minutes to 11Pm at night. Add to that the Ice machine, lift and noisy AC units and you have the perfect storm.if you are a light sleeper you have no chance because of the lack of solidarity in it's structure. For those guests who can put up with noise it provides a free shuttle to the subway into Boston. Free breakfast was also a bonus in a small area off the reception area and coffee was always available at no cost.In summary I have travelled to many parts of the world and this hotel for me rates as one of the worst but of course we all have different levels of expectation and for me it gave no real rest and or "Comfort"

review: It's a Comfort Inn so I wasn't expecting 4 or 5 star quality. That being said, the staff were incredibly nice. The best feature about the room, by far, was the bed. With 4 soft pillows, the firmness of the bed was great, the linens were soft and clean. Even the towels/wash clothes smelled nice--it was a very light fragrance but having stayed in budget hotels before, I thought the linens and towels were definitely a step up from regular budget hotels. The towels were also soft! The two things that kept me from giving this place a higher ranking was a dried water spot on the ceiling (there had clearly been a leak at some point) and the tv reception--some channels were all static, as in, you could see a picture but it was full of static and the channel guide provided in the room didn't match entirely to the actual channels. Parking is free--you get a parking pass to put in you car. There are some walkable places to eat nearby, including a grocery store across the street. Given the signs in the hotel parking lot to remove all valuables from your car and the same reminder given on the parking pass, I'm not sure I'd walk to the local places at night but that being said, I didn't hear any loud noise throughout the night so those warnings may just be common sense warnings. There is a $4.95/night charge added at check-in, it's supposed to be for phone/telecommunications, or something like that. I find it a bit bogus since I have a cell phone and had no intention of using the phone in my room but, it's $5 which is not worth an argument to me. I went down for breakfast just after 9:30 and found it to be well-stocked. There were 3 cereal options, 2 milk options, waffle maker, etc. I didn't use the shuttle service but I liked that they had a shuttle schedule and a subway map available in the lobby. According to the sign, the last shuttle officially left/picked up at 11pm but there was a note to see the staff if you needed a later pick-up. I stayed here because it was a few minutes away from the JFK presidential library & museum. If you're looking for a place to stay outside the city, consider this Comfort Inn. Room suggestion: Get a room that faces the front parking lot, the metro runs behind the hotel so I imagine rooms on that side hear the train every time it goes by.
response: Dear carmineruby, thank you for taking the time to share such a detailed review with us. We're pleased the Comfort Inn Boston could provide you with comfortable, convenient accommodations during your trip and that you felt you got good value for your money. We'll be sure to pass your compliments along to our staff. Thank you again for your feedback.
responder: Response from Andrea K, Assistant GM at Comfort Inn - Boston

review: Hotel is located so far from anything that it is very pricey to stay here without car. We had a rental car the whole time and we pick this hotel for it has free parking and it is easy to drive here to Key West, Everglades etc. There is absolutely nothing to do in the neighbourhood of this hotel. You can not jog or walk there just for fun. Every morning we left after breakfast and came straigh to bed, not a second too early. Some mornings breakfast was overcrowded and there was nothing to eat but bread. I could not get my morning tea since hot water in thermos was always luke warm.Room is spacious. A/C is too loud. Micro we did not use. Bathroom amenities lack hand soap as well as shower gel. Bath tub is useless unless you are a child. Whole floor is carpeted so it is not suitable if you have allergies. Beds are okay, not too hard. Coin laundry and dryers take only quarters. You can not open any window in a room and that is a huge minus. Nearby roard are very busy any time of a day so you will need earplugs to sleep. Plus the door to corridor is not soundproof.We did not have almost any contact with the staff. Housekeeping was friendly as was maintenance too. I had pleasure to meet manager Tulio only when checking out. He seemed genuinely friendly.

review: Upon arriving to this hotel, I was a bit skeptical. But after I entered my room, I was at ease. The hotel was clean and quiet. The room had a microwave, refrigerator, safe, and even a whirlpool. The hotel was conveniently located near Florida International University, where I was meeting a client and some students. I slept comfortably and the breakfast was okay. The staff was courteous but not as concerned or empathetic as I would have liked. (I'll explain) I woke up the next morning searching for my phone. I figured it had fallen through the crack of the mattress and the headboard. I reached down to discover all types of hidden treasures (not really). First I pulled up an old remote, which lead me to believe that they do not normally check the head of the beds because the room had a new remote. Next, I touched something that felt like satin. I immediately pulled the bed back and to my disgust I found a pair of panties (I would upload a picture but I don't want to offend anyone. I have one available by request.) How gross was that? I informed the hotel staff and they didn't seem the least bit alarmed or concerned. One of the receptionist even made an excuse saying the the cleaning person probably couldn't move the bed. I informed her that I, a very petite lady who barely weighs 120 lbs, had no trouble moving it so I don't see anyone else having a problem. She offered to send someone to clean the room, but I informed her I was checking out in a couple of hours so it was unnecessary. It kind of left a bad taste in my mouth. I kept thinking: 1) the room should've been thoroughly examined upon my arrival and 2) what if the person wearing those underwear last was infected by something. What offended me most is I have yet to receive a formal apology. I liked the hotel up until that point. Hopefully, your experience much more pleasant.
response: Hello Ms. B S,First, please allow me to apologize for what happened during your stay with us, I assure you steps have been taken to ensure that this does not happen again, to you or anyone else.Please know that a letter of apology was sent to the address on record (GA) on 02/10/2012.We are grateful that you stayed with us and hope that on your next trip to Miami you will give us an opportunity to host you again.
responder: Response from ToolsMiami, Manager at Comfort Suites Miami / Kendall

review: This hotel is in a great location, situated right between Copley Square and Boylston Street. It is within walking distance to many great restaurants and shops, and near a central MBTA station that can get you anywhere in the city pretty quickly! However, this hotel is pretty dated and is not of similar quality to other Courtyard Marriott properties. However, the rooms are comfortable and rather quiet, there is free, fast WIFI and the staff is friendly. If you can get this hotel for a good deal, I would suggest it. However, there is a Sheraton, a Westin, and a Marriott that are pretty close to this same location and usually around the same price or just a bit more expensive. Look elsewhere first, but this hotel is a basic, clean place to sleep if thats all you need!

review: We arrived at the Courtyard by Marriott on Essex Street on the rainy night of 12/23/15. After a long day of travel, then running in a downpour, we were cold, wet and tire, and the bright warm lobby was a welcome haven. Ever so softly in the background, Bing Crosby sang "I'll Be Home for Christmas." The desk clerk, Justin, treated us with a hushed courteousness that reinforced the pleasure of arriving at a small quiet hotel. I peeked into the breakfast room off the lobby, and imagined enjoying coffee and the morning paper at one of the little tables.Our room on the 8th floor was thoughtfully appointed with great lighting, good mattress and high-quality bedding.We were shocked in the morning to find the lobby transformed into a harsh, mindless, irritating space. Rock music was cranking and three TVs flashed and muttered on the walls. One older couple sat eating, sullen, not talking, music pelting them from overhead.The corporate goal must be to keep guests miserable in the public spaces. We love visiting Boston, and will be looking for a hotel that allows us to enjoy a quiet breakfast before starting the day.
response: Thank you so much for your review. It's great to hear how much you enjoyed your stay overall, however we are so sorry for the inconsistency regarding the public space. review: I stayed recently for several nights while in town for a convention. When I checked in, I was given room 701, and it was so tiny!! review: On April 29, I booked a 4-day vacation for myself and my son in Boston with Marriott via their 800 phone number for June 1st-4th. I am a Marriott rewards member for over 20 years and do some business and pleasure trips at their facilities. I applied my points which gave me the first night free. The other two nights were to be $322/night as per the customer service rep. I was given a confirmation number but was not emailed any kind of confirmation. I was emailed prior to my stay to let me know I didn‚Äôt have sufficient points to cover my stay but was well aware of that. When I arrived with my son I was told by Thy at the Front Desk that Monday nights rate was $617, almost double the rate I was confirmed for. I asked how that could be since I made my reservation back in April. I was told that because of demand and overbooking the rate was that amount. I was dumbfounded! I‚Äôd never book a stay anywhere out of town without knowing the price. How could they not honor a confirmed reservation? I got no help from the hotel so called the 800 number. They couldn‚Äôt/wouldn‚Äôt due anything to reduce the rate for Monday night. They made mention about the Stanley Cup Playoffs. The TD Bank Garden is right across the street but there were no hockey games till Thursday night. They said it would take 48 hours to resolve so I couldn‚Äôt take the chance and get billed for $617 for the last night. Unfortunately, we had to cancel out Monday night and make it a 3-day vacation. I feel this was outright price gouging along with horrible customer service. Megan at the front desk was supposed to give me a call within 48 hours after I arrived to look into it and didn‚Äôt. After I called on Monday to square away the bill I was told it would only be charged for the extra night and not charged for the first night with points. This would take 5-7 business days to resolve. The whole experience left a bad taste in my mouth with Marriott. Being in sales for over 30 years I still can‚Äôt imagine a company treating a Rewards member, let alone any customer, this way. Booker beware!
response: Thank you for taking the time to share your experience with us. It's never easy to read when a guests stay has been anything other than perfect. Unfortunately if you were not able to acquire the correct number of points required to stay with us, despite being emailed ahead of time, at property level we are left with the need to charge the prevailing rate of the day for the reservation. In these instances, we very much hope that the guest will communicate with us prior to arrival so that we may take steps to help however we can to get your reservation set up the way you prefer, offering the opportunity to purchase whatever points may be needed to satisfy the full stay ahead of time, so that a higher rate can be avoided. Given that the night you had opted to use your points happened to coincide with a Stanley Cup play off game, demand and rates became high across the city and the prevailing rate was not what you had expected. We hope to be able to discuss this further with you at a time of your convenience by telephone or email and would kindly ask that you reach out directly.
responder: Response from CourtyardNS, General Manager at Courtyard Boston Downtown/North Station

review: This CM feels somehwat dated - like time-travel to the 80ties...the lobby chairs are faded..they missed the whole Marriott corporate lobby upgrade campaign. That is good and bad. The bad thing is that the decor is dated and the furniture are worn. The good thing is that you can still get the old fashion breakfast buffet with omelette station. For frequent travelers: there is no VIP room and there is no free breakfast. They discontinued free breakfast this summer. Apparently there is no room upgrade either - I was sent to the disabled room next to the noisy ice mashine and elevator without prior warning as Platinum Elite..so your status doesnt buy you anything at this place. Rooms are as dated as the lobby...comes with the poor Courtyard bedding as any other CM. Only positive thing about the room is that they have the upgraded shampoo. TVs are smaller than normal. The pool is big enough to take a bath..not much more you can do in it..hot tub is luke warm...staff is soso...lots of minumum wage and the dressed up ones are friendly but somewhat "uncool"..must be a very strict and micromanaged place. Window AC is noisy as in most CMs...not as bad as in the CM Westchase. Parking and breakfast is basically another 30 bucks to the base price. So if you are looking for a boring overpriced place next to the galleria..this is the place,.

review: Let me first state that as a Marriott Platinum rewards member I think I have the required expertise of staying in many Marriott properties including courtyards to make this review.Housekeeping: Good: The rooms were clean: BAD: Anyone who travels knows that the housekeeping staff will use the slide lock to keep the door open when there are cleaning a room. I have not problem with this practice. however, no one wants to come back to there room in the late afternoon and see that housekeeping did not lock the door behind them and kept the lock extended to keep the door open. Luckily no one entered the room and stole anything. First I looked all over the hotel floor to see if maybe they were around in another nearby room. I could not find anyone from housekeeping on the floor. When I went down to the front desk, the front desk attendant showed little concern and just calmly stated "I will let housekeeping know".Rooms: Rooms are extremely small compared to most other courtyards. Also, there are little tiny gnats flying around the rooms that are annoying to say the least. I was travelling with a group of family members so I had the opportunity to be in several rooms on several different floors, all rooms had the same gnat problemsBathrooms: Again extremely small, virtually no counter space to set your overnight toiletries bag(s). If you are traveling as a single then the room size won't be an issue but be advise any more than 2 to a room will be uncomfortable.Amenities: Most courtyard's offer Starbuck's in the bistro along with other food and beverage items. While I don't like the Bistro concept Marriott has gone to it is a good alternative to no restaurant at all. Anyway, in every single courtyard I have stayed in, other than the Coconut Grove property, there is usually house brand coffee and ice water available in the lobby for guests. this property had no coffee for guests. With the prices this courtyard charges compared to other courtyards I would expect a little extra, but not here.Pool: the pool area is a plus for the hotel. The pool, is nice, it is clean and there are ample chairs. the one thing the management should do is to ask guests not to bring bottles near the pool. Every day I witnessed people bringing bottled beers to the deck area. This is very dangerous and the hotel should make it clear with a sign that no bottles allow in pool area.This same review will be forwarded to Marriott customer service. I realize they can't do anything about the room size, but issues with housekeeping, lack of services etc. should be acknowledged.Will not stay here again. Sorry there are too many other properties
response: Thank you for the feedback. I have shared with all departments to address your concerns (in particular the comments regarding rooms security, front desk response to issues and the gnats).I'm sorry the experience wasn't up to your expectations and we do hope you give us another try so that we can improve upon your experience.
responder: Response from Thomas L, Manager at Courtyard Miami Coconut Grove

review: This was an old apartment or condo building that was converted into a hotel. The room I had was on the 9th floor and consisted of a narrow entryway, a small closet, a smaller bathroom, and a bedroom. The view was of a parking deck and a parking deck. There was a small balcony that overlooked the ally where the dumpster was located. The pool was good as was the outdoor seating area. Unfortunately, the pool towels were kept in the outdoor eating area instead of the pool area. Also the water was very heavily chlorinated so you need to wear swimming goggles or close your eyes. Parking is another issue. You can park on the street for about $6 per day, but good luck finding any. The hotel charges $24 per day for valet parking. The Ritz-Carlton is just down the street so if you can get a good rate stay there; not here.
response: Thank you for sharing your feedback with us. Unfortunately, street parking is controlled by the city and costs $1.50 per hour. I will share your comments with the team regarding the pool. We hope to see you back in the Grove soon.
responder: Response from Thomas L, Manager at Courtyard Miami Coconut Grove

review: Stayed here a week thru New Year's Eve booked by my company. The location is decent...walking distance to Bayfront Park in the downtown area. Decent food options all over.The hotel is nice enough when you enter. Nice lobby with a little sundry store with snacks and such. The staff really shines...nice, nice people. They helped us with places to eat, did my laundry, got us cabs...all the stuff they are supposed to do, but with a smile on their faces.We ate in the restaurant/bar one late night and it was fair. Took quite a while to get the food, and was kind of expensive for what we got (club sandwich and fries) but what do you really expect from a hotel bar?The room was in some ways good, and in some ways bad.The good...HUGE room. King size bed, flat screen TV, a sitting area with couch and chair, work desk with nice chair and even some leftover room to spare. It really is probably the largest 'non-suite' room I have stayed in. I have stayed in Jr Suites in other locations that weren't this large.The bad...everything was just really old. They are in dire need of a make over. The furnishings looked old and very tired...the curtains were stained, and the carpet was wearing in places. The shower was old-looking, but great water pressure! I wanted to take a picture, but the toilet was REALLY ODD. It was set at an angle in the corner of the bathroom. It just looked really weird. Functional, though.Over-all with a little spit and polish this could be a really nice property, especially with the quality staff already in place and a downtown location that is near the airport, but not right on it.
response: Thank you for your comments!
responder: Response from Mariana S, Director of Operations at Courtyard Miami Downtown Brickell Area

review: My friend and I have stayed at this hotel for a number of years for an annual event in Miami. Generally speaking we've had no issues with this hotel and have been willing to pay the inflated fee during the event every year.This year we booked our reservation through Expedia (as we have every other year) at a rate of $400/night. Obviously, this accounted for the inflated price during the event as their normal rate is in the mid$100s.Upon arriving at the hotel this year, we were informed that our reservation was somehow "lost". The manager proceeded to inform us that "coincidentally" there was one room left at a rate of over $600/NIGHT!!!! Let that sink in... OVER $600 A NIGHT FOR A COURTYARD MARRIOTT!!The manager's excuse was that we shouldn't have been able to book a room for this weekend due to it being a black out period and that our $400/night rate did not reflect the rate during the black out period. This was a ridiculous argument given the fact that we were already willing to pay almost three times the normal rate.After having Expedia provide proof of the reservation to the hotel manager, and after arguing with them for approx 30 minutes, they were still unwiling to honor the rate in our reservation confirmation from Expedia.Finally, given that we had already traveled to the festival, bought tickets to the festival, and every other hotel in a 20 mile radius was fully booked, we had not other choice but to take the room at this absurd rate.Subsequently four months later neither Marriott or Expedia are able to resolve the matter.I've been a loyal customer and have paid extremely inflated rates at this hotel during the festival over the past ten years. However after their greedy tactics of trapping me into paying an absolutely ridiculous rate this year, I will not stay here again. I highly advise each of you to proceed with caution. I hope you heed this warning of this location practicing unscrupulous business practices. Given that they have scammed us for approx $500, I hope enough of you will avoid this location so that they loose ten times this amount in future business. I hope the extra cash was with it to them.
response: Thank you for sharing your experience.We apologize for any inconvenience this situation may have caused you. Unfortunately, Expedia is a third party and they never made the reservation in our system, the rate provided was our rack rate for the night for a worldwide music event (Ultra Music fest). The company you used never provided proof of reservation as requested after speaking with them in several occasions. Therefore, we consider the hotel should not be blamed for it.Roberto FernandezFront Office ManagerCourtyard by Marriott Miami Downtown
responder: Response from Mariana S, Front Office Manager at Courtyard Miami Downtown Brickell Area

review: This hotel is definitely clean, which is a big plus. However, to keep costs down, they do not cool their elevator or hallways. It is stifling, and it effects your room being able to become cool as well. I had my thermostat set to 50 degrees, and it never got colder than 73. They also do nothing for platinum Marriott Reward members. I got bonus points upon check-in (400) but was never asked my preference. There was also water in the room that had a tag that they would charge you $3.50. I assumed (my fault) that Platinum members wouldn't be charged for the water, as is customary in other hotels - not so. I would skip it and stay at the Marriott by the Airport. The Service is better, and free upgrades and concierge level is more suited to Platinum members.

review: We stayed here just one night on an overnight on our way to Canada. I chose it because of the location to the few things we were doing in our limited time -- and because it's a Marriott (love earning points). The positives first: The food and service in the Bistro ---very good. We had both dinner and breakfast in the Bistro just because of convenience and we were not disappointed. The room was large, clean, and beds very comfy. There ya go. Those were the positives - and most importants of course. HOWever ... at nearly $200 for one night, I kind of expected juuuuust a little more. I get that they were under construction --which I was aware of ahead of time. But, the young lady that checked us in had trouble describing how to get to the parking garage..did not tell us to make sure we brought our parking ticket in to get stamped or validated ...and also was not very clear about the Bistro. She said we could get room service. However, in our room, there was no menu, just an info sheet about the Bistro but nothing with any pricing and/or any thing to write with etc. (Which is why we went down to the actual restaurant to eat afterall). Then, when checking out, that lady, not overly friendly I might add, could not explain what the extra $40 on our bill was. At first she said it was for our dinner last night. We paid cash. Then she said it was for our breakfast. We had vouchers for free breakfast ---annnnnd we had not been TO breakfast yet. Finally I asked her for a complete printout ---which she said was being emailed to me. I said, Please may I have a printout. Sheeesh. Finally she did and OH hey ..the $40 was for PARKING. I knew there was a parking fee, I did not know it would total up to $40!!! So we had a discussion about the parking. We went to eat -- (again, very nice and the servers in there were wonderful). Then I wanted to use the lobby floor restroom before we went to garage to leave. Ya had to have a code to get in. The same girl at the desk was still kind of snippy about it. :( Finally we head out. OH gee ... you either PAY as you are leaving or ya should have had the ticket validated (no it didn't say that ANYwhere). So I walked back up to the lobby ..the same girl says ... "you could have pressed the intercom button"... I said, Hey, you could have said, OH BY THE WAY, may I validate your ticket for you now that you have paid $40 or be sure to press the intercom button and I will let you out". I went back downstairs and sure enough, there was a tiny little button that said "intercom" (my friend hadn't seen that either. SO ... disappointing considering the number of Marriott's I've stayed in around the world. Just sayin' ...... but ...the beds were very comfy. That part was great!
response: Hello malpal,Thank you for sharing your feedback with us. I'm glad to hear that your sleep quality was at a comfortable high and the service you received in the Bistro was top notch. We strive for a smooth and seamless stay and apologize that part of yours was not up to par. Please know that it is not standard for our staff to be vague or misleading in any way. We will use your feedback as a learning opportunity and share it with the appropriate team members so that this does not happen again in the future. Should you have a chance to stay with us again, please allow us to show you our utmost gratitude and high quality service we expect of all of our staff members.In hospitality,Alina CGuest Service Representative
responder: Response from Alina C, Administrative Assistant at Courtyard Seattle Downtown/Lake Union

review: The Good: We visited Seattle for the Tulip Festival and finished up with some sight-seeing downtown. The Courtyard Marriott has an excellent location on the border of Pioneer Square. Centrally located for pretty much everything downtown. We walked to the Pier and had excellent meals at several restaurants very conveniently located. One of our tours picked us up directly from the hotel. The rooms, and beds in particular, were very comfortable. The Bad: This is a Marriott. It's a nice hotel, but it is not a luxury hotel. Our room was over $300 per night. Which was high for the quality, but fine because of the excellent location. Unfortunately, there is also no realistic overnight parking options. Because we had been touring the Tulip Festival, we had a rental car. If we stayed downtown Seattle again, I would probably drop off my family at the hotel. Return the rental to the airport and then take the light rail train back to the downtown area. Parking at the hotel was valet only and $40 per night and then of course, you also tip the valet. So, at a minimum, your stay is going up 15% a night. Quick word of warning - when using the valet, there is a bike path between it and the hotel. You really have to keep your eyes open or you will get hit by a bicyclist. Luckily nobody in our group got hit, but it is not the most safe valet location. The Ugly: Lobby and interior of the rooms were typical, nice Marriott. However, some of the rooms (our room was one of several) exterior windows face an old (abandoned?) building with broken windows, graffiti, etc. Horrible view so make sure you are picky when choosing the room. Also, it has a heated pool but it is not well-taken care of and really needs an update.
response: Thank you for your review, I am happy you enjoyed the location. We recently underwent a full renovation so the mattresses and box springs are all new. I am glad you found them comfortable. Our rates fluctuate seasonally with the demand in the market. Generally our rates are lower than most others in downtown Seattle. Being that we are an historic building, we do not have a parking garage in the hotel so we must lease garage space on the next block, hence the valet only option. Parking is at a premium in all of downtown Seattle, so I always encourage guests to use public transportation if they can do without a car while visiting. I sincerely apologize for the view from your room. The rooms on that side of the building face another brick building and therefore obscure any city view from that side on the lower floors.I appreciate your comments and I hope you will stay with us again in the future.Regards,David
responder: Response from David K, Manager at Courtyard Seattle Downtown/Pioneer Square

review: This hotel is decent. I wouldn't rave about it but it was ok for our needs. We were totally unaware of the parking situation and prices. The website leads you to believe that close by self park is free where as valet parking is $42 per night. Close by is close but charges plenty with no in and out privileges and a 10 hour max on the weekends. Street parking is available at night only and must be off the street by 8:00am. Housekeeping at this hotel is spotty. The positive is that it's close to the ball parks and within walking distance of the waterfront. There are a few decent places to eat near bay. Also, front desk staff are very nice, helpful and friendly. I would stay here again, but would hope that things improve as far as parking and housekeeping.
response: Thank you for your review of the Pioneer Square Courtyard. I would like to apologize if our website was confusing in regards to parking. As you mentioned, the only parking that is affiliated with the hotel is the valet parking. Other options are other parking garages in the immediate area and metered street parking (which is free from 6pm-8am). However, I am happy to hear about the Front Desk staff and that you would stay here again. I will pass on your comments to our Housekeeping Manager and hope you do stay with us again soon.Laura SchlesFront Office Manager
triptype: Trip type: Traveled as a couple
responder: Response from Laura S, Front Office Manager at Courtyard Seattle Downtown/Pioneer Square

Be careful with reservation here‚Äî I realized the rate had gone down a lot from when I reserved, and I overpaid. Free WiFi is fairly good speed. No bfast included, and most bfast options are approx $17-25. All factors considered, this hotel didn‚Äôt offer value for money. I won‚Äôt return.

review: This Marriott Courtyard is in the middle of nowhere. It is close to Logan airport, that is the big plus. The staff is kind and friendly, very much so. The rest is pretty bad. While the lobby is pretty nice, the rooms are pretty sad. Bathrooms to be exact. The tub in our room 1005 had peeling epoxy, the sink was cracked, the shower head was clogged in places. The air conditioner was intermittent and noisy, it also felt as if the air was tainted with some sort of moisture from the blower. The fire alarm light flashed all night long. The windows are not noise insulated, we were on the 10th floor and every time a truck pass the hotel, we heard it, all night long. The bed sagged in the middle. And so on. The bar, restaurant was just okay. We had our drinks and a ‚Äúfeeding‚Äù. Food really boring. That‚Äôs about it.

All of our mattresses were replaced a year ago during our room renovation but will take a look at the room you stayed in. Thank you for choosing to stay with us and I hope you give us another chance.

review: I was very disappointed during check in. The front desk was very persistent with needing a credit card for incidentals (per our company, we are not required to give our personal card for incidentals). The front desk associate said she "wouldn't not give me a room, until she had a card on file", even though the rooms were already paid for. So I waited for 30+ minutes to get the problem squared away. At no point did the manager on duty come out to try and rectify the problem, so I was left at the front desk wasting valuable time.This property seems outdated. My room was clean, but very small. There was no refrigerator or microwave. I did enjoy the shared pool, which I believe is actually on Marriott property. The airport shuttle runs frequently and promptly. This is an average hotel, do not expect anything spectacular here... There's no attention to detail. Fine for a one night stay before your next flight out.I hope the GM takes a better look at the quality of service offered at the front desk, and the overall appearance of the hotel.
response: Thank you for choosing to stay with us and thank you for your feedback. I apologize for any miscommunication that occurred at check-in. I truly apologize that a member of y leadership team did not offer personal assistance to you during this situation. I have shared your feedback with them and I will be taking immediate corrective action. Moreover, I have shared your feedback regarding the lack of attention to detail with the entire hotel staff. We hope that you will consider staying with us during a future visit to Miami. We would love to welcome you back and provide you an exceptional experience.

review: Definitely a mixed bag at this new hotel. We chose it for the great location and the fact that we were traveling on points.The hotel is clean, new and nicely decorated. However...while I love the concept of laminate flooring in a hotel to keep things cleaner, the execution failed as we could hear EVERYTHING from upstairs. Another downside was that you could only control the thermostat to a certain point...no air conditioning below 68 degrees. For people who sleep warm, this was a definite bummer. Housekeeping was interesting...each day we couldn‚Äôt find important items and had to search the room...eventually finding them placed in random drawers or the closet (we didn‚Äôt unpack any of our items into these places, so it was an odd thing for them to put them there.)We also chose this hotel for the queen size beds vs. the standard doubles in many hotels. But the beds were so uncomfortable, we actually checked out a night early to drive home and sleep in our own beds.Parking is a ridiculous $42 a night. I also just called the hotel to check on some charges to my credit card and they have no record of us checking out early (we turned in our keys and spoke to a desk attendant)All in all, we wouldn‚Äôt visit again. Overpriced but adequate.
response: Hello and thank you for choosing to stay with us on your visit to Santa Monica. I am sorry to hear that your stay was not exemplary. I will pass on your comments to the staff so we can improve on the areas you mentioned. We hope you do give us another try in the future.

review: Have been a member of Marriott for over 10 years. Traveled countless hotels. Never had an issue that could not be resolved until this night. I'm not a picky traveler - if the room is clean and plumbing works - it's good for me.Arrived into Santa Monica Courtyard at 11 PM. No parking left and no valet. "You are checking in late, so it's your problem". Wait what? A check in before midnight in Marriott system is not a late check-in by any means. As a business traveler, the times I've been arriving to Courtyards at 1 AM or later due to late flights and other travel issues has been countless. Never been an issue. Well, all right.Walk into the room. It's smoked in. It's so heavily smoked in, cleaning crew has lef the window open to try and alleviate the smell. It's so febreezed, you can practically see Febreeze in the air. Turn around and walk down: "I'm sorry, what's going on with the room?" - "Oh, you are checking in late, so we gave away your room and you get this one, this is the last room left. No, we can't do anything else for you. Want some more Febreeze or an ozone machine? We can give you a discount. Oh, and our shift is up, so sayonara, sucker".Wow. No help with transfer to another hotel, nothing. A hapless fella with 4 weeks on the job could only void the reservation and cancel the charges. Corporate was no help: "we'll log the case for you"Of course, you can't leave this review in Marriott system unless you stayed at Marriott. Well, at least TripAdvisor is always here.
response: Thank you for choosing to stay at the Courtyard Santa Monica and providing your honest feedback on the Guest Satisfaction Survey.Providing the highest level of hospitality is our number one priority and we sincerely apologize for falling short of meeting your expectations.Once again, thank you for taking the time to share your feedback. We appreciate you choosing to stay with us during these unusual times.
responder: Response from Shuki Koushandeh, Other at Courtyard by Marriott Santa Monica

review: This is really a Beverly Hills dormitory. Long, loud, non-carpeted corridor with unbelievably tiny sleeping pods, masquerading as guest rooms. These sleep chambers are barely big enough for one double bed and you can hear both the TV and all telephone conversations of your fellow dorm residents. Cement floors, cement showers - If it was locked from the outside - one would it a jail cel. The crime is I had to pay for this coffin.I was awakened 3x at night by what sounded like sirens. It was in fact the screeching pipes whistling through other chamber showers. The cost is high, the rooms are miniscule and the parking is expensive (not mentioned prior). The only positive comment is its location - which is easy walking distance to the center of Beverly Hills shopping district. As is so often the case - if the price looks too good to be true - it definitely is. Traveler beware.
response: Thank you for your response. While some of our rooms are built for single occupancy we also do offer King rooms and a 2 bedroom suite that may be better suited for you in the future.
