review: Our stay was very uncomfortable but mostly due to a bad mattress so in all fairness it may have been just the luck of the draw. We have been married for 40 years. Our stay was with the compliments of our son and daughter in law. They told us it was a boutique hotel just a couple of blocks from Rodeo and Beverly Drive and some wonderful restaurants were just around the corner. It sounded fun. We were told the hotel was 100% booked and there were no upgrades. Our room was very small which didn't bother us greatly as that can be common in upscale areas such as Paris, Tokyo, San Francisco and New York. When I asked I was told by the desk clerk the hotel was rated 3 stars. The room was more like 2 stars but the location was probably 4 stars. If you want to stay in Beverly Hills and close to Rodeo Drive it is a good bet but downsize your expectations for the room experience. Our room was probably their smallest and when I asked at the desk what the price would be for a room similar to ours I was told it was on special for $199. We did not sleep at all that night. We were not on our honeymoon and very accustomed to our own space. :) This bed brought us much closer together because the bed sloped to the middle. If someone could hear us from the hall or an adjacent room they would have thought we were on our honeymoon. The springs squeaked so loudly from the movement of our lungs expanding with normal breathing. We had a sense of humor about it when we would both wake up when one of us would roll over. Sometimes you just have to make lemonade. I have sent the manager an email. It will be interesting to hear his response. One more note. If you look at their website it states that Gregory Peck is the owner. Gregory Peck died in 1993 after a long and industrious career. I think it is time for an updated website. Keep that in mind.
response: Thank you for the review. We appreciate the feedback. I'm sorry to hear that the mattress was not up to your standards. We have since replaced the actually bed-frame in order to remedy this problem.Also, Gregory Peck is in fact still the owner. He is has no relation to the actor Gregory Peck.
triptype: Trip type: Traveled as a couple
responder: Response from crescentbeverlyhills, Manager at Crescent Hotel Beverly Hills

review: I am generally a fan of boutique hotels and didn't come in the door here expecting the trappings of big and fancy, but I was very disappointed with my stay here. My first impression was the valet, who wasn't at his station, but around the corner smoking a cigarette or something. When he did come over, rather than welcoming me, he first admonished me that I needed to back the car up a foot because I was encroaching the red zone. I grabbed my bag and walked into the lobby - tiny but cute, with a well-stocked bar and music playing. There was a loud group sitting in the lobby drinking and chatting, and the acoustics made the decibel level even greater, plus I think they were trying to talk over the music. Ugh. The bright ray of sunshine was the young man at the desk - Justice, I think he said his name was (or at least over the noise, I that's what I thought I heard). He was delightful, someone who really knows what the service/hospitality business is about. In addition to checking me into my room, he helped find a charger for my phone and offered empathy for my tedious travel day. Every hotel could use someone like him.No elevator here, so if you have a second floor room, I'd suggest going light on the bag. Walking down the hallway, it was clear to me that his place was some kind of apartment conversion. The rooms are appointed nicely...the bed was fantastic, TV modern, nice amenities, and the AC works great, which was important since it was almost 100 here today. Downsides to the room - you can hear EVERYTHING in the rooms on either side. When the guy in the next room got into the shower at 3:30 am, you would have thought he was in the shower in my room the water in the pipes was so loud. The wireles works, but I had to sit on the floor near the door to get it to stay connected consistently. And something I thought I'd never say, but the hot water is too hot! There isn't any safety feature to keep it from getting to scalding...it was difficult to get it warm and then all of a sudden it was dangerous. I bought a bloodspot coupon, so this room only cost me $115, which is incredible for any establishment in Beverly Hills and I appreciate the proximity to all of the shopping, etc. But if I had paid the full price (I think $235) for this room, I'd be fuming.
response: Thank you for the response. We are sorry to hear about the valet staff that was at the property that day and we will do our best to remedy the situation you spoke of. We're happy to hear you loved our amenities and we hope you come visit us again soon.
responder: Response from crescentbeverlyhills, Manager at Crescent Hotel Beverly Hills

review: Travel around the world has been seriously diminished due to COVID-19. Even when traveling, hotels and airlines are putting in special measures to ensure a safe and healthy travel experience. I have been limiting my travels due to the pandemic, but recently I had to travel to Houston. I have been to Houston many times and stayed at various hotels throughout the city, mostly in the Galleria area. When I was looking this time, I found a good deal at the Doubletree in the Galleria area. I have stayed here twice (see reviews here) and the experience was mixed - the rooms were nice but the service bad - but I decided to give it another try.The hotel has gone through some renovations on the inside (and this was evident in my previous stay in 2017) and since then the only additions have been due to COVID, which included partitions around the check-in desk, markers on the floor for social distancing, wipes next to the elevator, and signs stating masks were required. Other than that, everything was the same including how small the hotel entrance is; the layout of the hotel is such that you have the hotel building, the parking garage, and a small connector between the two. As you enter the connector, the parking garage is to your right, the connector in the middle, and the hotel on the left; the entrance is small generally and gets more crowded once there is a rush. Both valet and self-parking are available.The lobby itself is wide and spacious. The waiting area is right in front, while the check-in desks are to the left and the elevators and meeting rooms are to the right. As both the meeting rooms and elevators are in the same direction, it can become a bit crowded when there events taking place. I have stayed at other hotels during the pandemic (see review here) and their restrictions were far more strict than what was done here. There was no restriction on limiting the hotel to only guests so anyone could enter and exit as they please. Also, even though the state had mandated a mask-wearing policy and the hotel had signs requesting masks be worn, there was no enforcement or verbal reminders regarding mask wearing. In terms of social distancing, the only stickers on the floor were the ones in front of the check-in counters and they were not adhered to by most guests (nor enforced by the hotel staff). Check-in was okay but there was no customer service aspect - no greeting, no welcoming a Hilton Honors member, and not checking the reservation before asking questions, in fact it was the bare minimum of service expected and required; even the cookies, which are normally handed out at the beginning had to be requested. I received the key and proceeded to my room.The waiting area for the elevators can become crowded very quickly as there are 4 elevators all converging onto the same waiting area. They did have wipes for guests to use to wipe down the surface, but this was at your personal preference. Also, other hotels had enforced either a minimum number of guests in the elevators or only same-household groups in the elevators; none of that was mentioned nor enforced here and it was basically to each their own how they wanted to proceed. Previously, given my status, I have been upgraded to a junior suite and those rooms, while outdated, are quite spacious; this time I was not upgraded so I was given a standard Doubletree room.As you enter the room, on the left was the bathroom which contained a toilet, a shower/tub, a sink with lots of counter space. The bathroom was standard with standard amenities and toiletries needed to be requested from the front desk. Further inside the room, on the left were two double beds with a nightstand in the middle. The beds were generally comfortable, decent in size and overall good in sleep comfort. Across from the beds, against the wall, was a console that had a TV on top, an open shelf with the coffee/tea as well as ice bucket, drawers on the bottom, a fridge on the bottom, and a small table next to it. There was a large window across one wall and in between the window and the bed was a chaise lounge chair. There was a lot of furniture in the room and given the amount of things in the room, the standard size of the room, and then add people to that, the room felt small and cramped and some of the furniture needed to be removed to make the room feel more open.The hotel is full-service so there are many amenities for the guests to enjoy including a pool, a gym, meeting rooms, business center, restaurant, parking garage, and wifi. As I said earlier, parking was a nightmare both times I stayed here; you have to pay for parking so considering it requires payment, you think they would come up with a better solution. The gym also needs to be remodeled as its small and is located on the 3rd floor, right next to other rooms (it looks like they converted two rooms into a gym). The business center was 3 computers in the open lobby on the other side of the check-in desks. There was complimentary printing, but there was also a lot of noise; the wifi was complimentary and provided decent speeds.Overall, its an average hotel in the Galleria area. Plus points are the location, the hotel's signature cookies, and the spacious rooms and full-size fridge in the suites. Negatives include inconsistent and poor customer service and horrible (paid) parking situation, and particularly to covid no enforcement or adherence to public health-related guidelines. Given the horrible parking situation, the lack of adherence to public health guidelines and overall the general lack of service provided this was my last time staying at this hotel.
response: Dear 0504Traveller,It is always a treat to welcome back our repeat guests and we thank you for settling in again. Our team appreciates your thorough and thoughtful review and while we are warmed to read that you enjoyed a great night‚Äôs sleep on our DoubleTree beds and our ideal location, we are sorry to learn of your disappointments.We love the cookies too and given the pandemic, we are offering these upon request as we appreciate some travelers would prefer only pre-packaged treats. We are sorry if this was disappointing, but the health and wellness of our guests and DoubleTree colleagues is our greatest priority. Your added comments regarding our social distancing efforts are appreciated and we hope you noted our many Hilton CleanStay efforts, which included the removal of toiletries and other contact surfaces from the room, the removal of lobby furniture to create social distancing, app-based check-in and check-out and more. We thank you for sharing your observations and we hope you have confidence in knowing that this will serve as a coaching conversation with our team. On behalf of all of us, the pleasure was ours and we hope you might one day join us again so we can restore your confidence in an enjoyable Galleria visit.All the best,The DoubleTree Team
responder: Response from B P, Other at DoubleTree by Hilton Hotel & Suites Houston by the Galleria

hotel: Doubletree by Hilton Grand Hotel Biscayne Bay
review: The overall trip was finei - hotel was overall clean and the staff was generally nice. I did not have any issues with check in, but unfortunately the last impression of the hotel was very uncomfortable and one that the guests leave with.Main issue is one of the bellhoppers. I forgot his name, but he was a semi older gentleman with a white, shortish haircut. When I asked the front desk if I could temporary store a luggage for 2 hours, he was the person they called. The very FIRST words he said to me was "I work for tip." I replied okay, as it is not unusual to tip later on, and shortly after he gives me the ticket connecting to the luggage #. Immediately after giving the card, he repeats again "I work for tip." I asked him if I can tip after, as that was what I was used to. He just stands there repeating "I work for tip." Then he stands there staring at me. It was very uncomfortable. I have never met a bellhopper or other service staff that aggressive and demands to be paid tip upfront and will NOT move or help you out until so. It was extremely rude. It is up to you to decide, whether to tip or just hope for the best that your luggage was safe. Even if you asked for another bellhopper, it is uncomfortable, as this guy knows exactly where your luggage will be stored and what it looks like. I was pretty much forced to tip on the spot, otherwise you do not know what he will do with your luggage. My trust for the hotel went from 100% immediately to 10%, because of this guy. On top of that, it was near impossible to find him again, as expected. Obviously he got a great deal. $ for putting your luggage somewhere, and then running off. As expected, he would not be around to help you retrieve your luggage. It screws over not just the customer, but also the other bell hoppers who undoubtedly will be faced with an uncomfortable situation when they retrieve your bags. The other bell hoppers will not know that you already tipped the first time. Juan, on the other hand, was another bell hopper who I met and is an amazing gentleman by his actions toward other guests that I saw. He was very pleasant to work with, who was tipped generously afterwards.If anyone does choose this hotel, I would avoid the first bellhopper in particular. Unfortunately I do not know his name at the time, but just be on the lookout and extra cautious around him.
response: Dear Guest, I am extremely sorry to hear you did not have a good experience with one of our staff members. Customer service is our number #1 priority and we will use your feedback to continue improving. Please give us another opportunity during your next visit to Miami.Best Regards,Kreick RoveloDirector of Operations

review: The front desk staff are very friendly and professional. They will help you in anyway they can. However, the room is very small at this hotel. It is more like a dorm with a bathroom. There is no place to place or open your bags. You must place your bags on the bed in order to get things out. There is only chair in the entire room. The hotel does provide two bottles of complementary drinking water. The A/C and heater control does not work. No matter what temperature you set it, the fan is the only thing working and blowing. The room has a very small closet that can only fit three winter jackets in it. The walls in the room are super thin. You can hear everything your neighbor says. Bathroom doors and toilet seat closing could also be heard. At the middle of night, the plumbing can be heard -like a waterfall. Every time some one from the floor above flushes, you can hear a loud pop noise. The elevator doors and ding could also be heard in the room. The fire alarm has a very annoying twin red flash every 30 seconds. It gets very annoying when you are trying to sleep. The bathroom wash basin does not drain either. The same is true of the toilet. The toilet decides when the water will flush. If you are flushing the toilet after a number 2, you are chancing it. The room has two trash cans. One in the bathroom and one underneath the coffee machine. They are so small that two coffee cups will fill them. As for maid service, they either clean in the early morning before 9 am or at 3pm. The maid will just stock up the amenities and towels. The maid will not change your bed linen even if you have request the linen to changed. Some of the towels do have stains on them. You may need to bring your own or have disposable ones. The hair dryer makes noise, but does not blow out hot or warm air. You may need to air dry your hair after showering. The corners on the bed are very sharp too, so do be careful when you walk by them. The hotel does provide a free breakfast. It is nothing special- boiled eggs, yogurt, boxed cereals, bagels, pastries, coffee, tea, juices,instant oatmeal, oranges, apples and hot chocolate. I would stay away from the boiled eggs. They have a strong vinegar smell and taste. The hotel does provide tongs for the getting the eggs. I have seen some guests use their hand to retrieve the eggs. The hotel does have one microwave in the entire building. It is hidden on the bottom shelve in the lounge. The hotel is about one block from the 168th street subway station, and two blocks away from the Columbia Medical Center. Be warn this area has very limited restaurant selections. Many restaurants will not deliver to this address. The ones that do deliver will charge a hefty delivery charge. The surrounding area is not that safe after dark. You may not want to venture off the main path.
response: Hello John,Thank you for staying with us and writing such a detailed review of your experience.We are happy to hear that staff and service were to your liking! On the other issues and topics, I do hope you reached out to manager regarding all the issues and throughout your stay to help rectify all or any of the inconsistencies you did find during your stay. I see you did a very close and thorough review of all the hotels features and amenities, and for any issues and problems, I must sincerely apologize to you. I hope that you'll give us another chance and possibly come back so we can turn it all around.Best Regards,Mario - Front Desk Manager
responder: Response from Marian T, Front Office Manager at Edge Hotel

review: All of the staff we interacted with were extremely friendly and accommodating. However, we barely slept a wink at this hotel. Our first room was by a noisy group of people and the walls are paper-thin so you can hear everything. We moved rooms, and got a somewhat better night of sleep although the AC unit made some strange noises. The worst part is that you are only a block and a half away from a medical center so ambulances are constantly passing by with sirens at all hours of the night. We also got more noisy guests nearby the second night, who were clearly smoking in their room, so that smell along with their chatter, the doors slamming all night and the elevator kept us up. The entire hotel is very small and cramped (rooms included) so you hear everything on your floor. Breakfast was fine, just a little stale and they started to pack it up before 10AM (also no one told us where or when breakfast was). Valet parking is expensive but street parking is next to impossible to find close by. Very convenient to the Armory Track; otherwise not much to offer and probably would not stay there again.

review: The hotel was clean, great location, nice decor. But... our second day here, the hotel maid accidentally threw all our orders away from a trade-show we exhibited at the day before. They were in a bag that was sitting on our desk. Not by the trash. We went outside, dug through the garbage for almost 2 hours until we finally found them. The hotel staff did not want us to dig through the trash, and kept saying they would never throw stuff away that wasn't in the garbage can. Digging through the trash on a busy street in NYC is not how I wanted to spend my night, but I found the bag with my office supplies and orders in it, so I forgave the maid for throwing them away, despite the panic it caused. The next morning the maid knocked on my hotel door. She had gotten in trouble and asked if I had found my orders. I said "yes". She wanted me to tell the staff that I had found them. I said that they already knew I found them because they sat and watched my husband and I dig through the trash. She did not apologize for throwing our stuff away, and refused to make our bed the next few days that she was scheduled to work. I can forgive her for mistakenly throwing our trash away, but I'm still annoyed by the way she and the hotel staff treated us like we were an inconvenience to them by going through their trash. We are scheduled for another tradeshow in August, but we will be looking elsewhere for accommodations.

review: Let me begin by saying that our family exclusively stays at Hilton properties. Our stay at this Embassy Suites on the 14th and 15th of July had its fair share of ups and downs.Pros:This hotel is conveniently located right off of the expressway with plenty of food and entertainment options within a very short drive. We were in town to watch an Astros game and got to the stadium in about 25 minutes.The breakfast is definitely a plus with this property. Plenty of options were available and the wait staff was working at a feverish pace to ensure that all the tables were cleaned promptly to accommodate the large crowd on hand.The managers reception was great. I dont drink but my wife enjoyed the wide variety of options and snacks that were available.The property seems very new so it has the ‚Äúwow‚Äù factor that a lot of the older Embassy Suites are missing.Cons:Check in took a while as there was only one individual at the front desk working.I asked if there were any available upgrades for me to purchase and I got the ‚ÄúJulia Roberts‚Äù look when she asked to try on a dress on Rodeo Drive. The only reason I had asked was because the check in feature on the Hilton app told me there were plenty of upgrades available that morning but I failed to confirm it. Wasn‚Äôt a huge deal but I was more upset with the response than the availability.Upon arrival two dirty towels and a wine glass were left next to our door. I thought that was fairly disgusting and the gentleman that setup our pack n play walked right passed it twice and didn‚Äôt bat an eyelash.OUR ROOM DID NOT GET CLEANED! We left for the Astros game at exactly 11:45am and returned to the hotel at 9:00pm to find the room hadn‚Äôt been touched. We are by no means messy people but when you have an infant cleanliness is a priority. I called the front desk to inquire and the gentleman that answered the phone apologized and offered us dessert. I thought I was hearing things and he repeated dessert. I told him none of us were hungry but a clean room was a priority to us. I hung up and got in touch with Hilton corporate via the Hilton app. Submitted a request and got a response within seconds. They informed me that I would be moved to another room. I went downstairs and the poor front desk gentleman was completely overwhelmed. The phone was ringing off the hook and there was a line of other guests waiting. At this point my 15 month old reached her peak tiredness and as many parents know breaking a toddler‚Äôs routine is dangerous. We got our new room and proceeded to move our endless amount of bags across the hall and the hotel issued pack n play refused to cooperate so I literally had to carry it opened down the hall which was no easy feat. hotel: Embassy Suites by Hilton Boston at Logan Airport
review: I had a very nicely acquainted "standard" Embassy Suites room. I will say, it is conveniently located right behind the rental car building at Logan.the Lobby areas, restarant and bar are well lit and very open. the pool is smallish, but adequate. The gym...is a small hotel gym...I've been in better and worse. the equipment is newer, but this isn't a Gold's Gym or a YMCA quality selection.They only offer Valet parking...which was not mentioned by my TA, nor did I find it readily noted on any of the standard travel websites. IT IS $51 PER DAY and you have no other choice. It is cheaper to par your car over at the airport and walk over to the lot daily. I guess if you can Uber/Lyft it, or take the rail...or just staying here for the night, then...not an issue...but dang...1/5th of my nightly cost is for the car...I kind of feel like it should get to come up to the room with me for that price...reverse the numbers and it is a bit more reasonable.I ate at the restaurant and the food was "meh", not spectacularly "New England", but the seafood was fresh and the taste was appealing.At the end f the day, if you need to stay by Logan for an early morning flight and are dropping off your rental car, or you are arriving late and want to crash for a night before renting a car and leaving...it is not a bad place and you get the value you pay for.
response: Dear hurricaneJoe,Thank you for your comments regarding your recent stay the Embassy Suites Boston Logan Airport. hotel: Embassy Suites by Hilton Houston Downtown
review: Hotel is newer and nicely set up. Unfortunately, the A/C unit was not working properly so the heat and humidity were unpleasant to the point where there was no rest at night. Maintenance did come to fix the A/C unit but a puddle of water had gathered on the carpet that they were planing to address a little later but that didn't happen. However, the attached restaurant - Hearsay - was good. Not a large menu but the food is abundant. Room service was very quick but costly - expect 21% surcharge plus a $5 delivery fee before tip. It's much less expensive to eat in the restaurant which always had people in there but was never so full I couldn't get a seat. The free breakfast was good. Scrambled eggs, sausage, bacon, and another breakfast staple along with made-to-order omelets, etc. The evening reception wasn't bad, either. Essentially what you'd expect from Embassy. I couldn't find the bar area, but wasn't really looking very hard since I had only planned to have a soda with my snacks. Oddly enough, I didn't see anyone checking to ensure the participants were really hotel guests as I've experienced with most other Embassy Suites. Overall, good atmosphere, good food, great staff but just needs to get some of the kinks out for a good night's stay.

review: I spent almost a week at this hotel downtown, unfortunately through April 1st, when the Final Four started: the last couple of night I could hardly sleep due to the beeping sirens of fork lift trucks working in the adjoining parking lot in preparation for later concerts - unnecessary noise, since nobody was around at night. Notwithstanding my room was on the 15th floor, I was kept awake by the noise. Had I known, I would have asked to prepare the sofa bed in the living room, which being internal was somehow sheltered. For the rest, the stay was ok, even if the a/c unit was not well balanced between bedroom and living room, and even if their free shuttle service does not extend to The Galleria shopping mall like other hotels downtown (over the phone, I had been advised otherwise). I would have appreciated being advised of the Final Four and the associated noise to be expected. So, all I remember of the stay at this hotel is the last two sleepless nights. I think I am generous in giving a rating of 3, and I doubt I will go back.

review: This is a very difficult review for me to write as I loved the hotel itself. It is modern, clean ( and housekeeping seem to be the only staff in this hotel who cares about the guest) and the location is okay ( 20 minutes maximum walk to anywhere I wanted to be). The room has a mini gym set up in it and the bathroom has one of the best showers I have had in a long time. The television has great channels, love the infused water available in the lobby. This hotel is one of the ‚Äúgreenest‚Äù I have stayed in and love it for this. You are given a plastic water bottle to keep so none of those throw away bottle and plastic cups. The coffee cups are paper and the toiletries are in dispensers. So much good about the hotel and then you get the staff (apart from housekeeping). What a let down! The worst in my living memory! My checkin was so mehhhhh! The young lady saw me as a nuisance rather than a valued Platinum IHG member. First time ever at an IHG property where my status was not once recognised! Every time I had an any interaction with the front desk staff it was as if I was a bother! On my checkout the young man had his pizza box and can of coke on the desk and was watching something on his laptop. Once again I was bothersome! On my arrival night which was very late, as I was waiting for the elevator to go to my room I heard the young man at the bar speaking to two other men ( assuming they had to be friends as hopefully that would not be a conversation with guests) about their sexual conquers with women. I am pleased no ladies were around to hear this utterly inappropriate conversation ( the bar is right by the elevators). I think a problem might be staff do not seem to wear any kind of uniform here and so forget they are at work? Training seems to be seriously lacking and the importance of the guest is certainly not a priority for these staff. A big let down for the hotel and this hotel is a big let down for the IHG brand. My comment about the staff is not the first one, it seems to be a reoccurring theme with the other reviews I have read on Tripadvisor but it appears that whoever is reviewing these at the hotel and IHG have tin ears as there just seems to be no improvement over time. What a pity what could be a great hotel is so badly let down by its staff!

I trust that the steps taken will improve your overall lodging experience on your next visit.I hope you choose us again!Best regards,Clayton G.Case ManagerIHGService

review: Our flight was delayed due to weather conditions and we didn't get to Miami until around 9pm. review: We stayed here again after a Belltown suite hotel turned out to be an apartment building with no ability to hold our bags til check in. Once again we found the staff helpful and efficient. The rooms were, once again, clean and free of odors. The hotel is right across the street from the library, for those so oriented and just down from the convention center, which had the hotel booked the next night forcing us to move on. We‚Äôd booked through Expedia for just over $100, as last time. For that amount these small rooms, typical for an older hotel, are a good value, especially given the location. Convention rates were closer to $600 a night, way way over what is reasonable. If you want a downtown hotel, close enough to King street station, Pikes Market and Pioneer Square, yes, this is a nice inexpensive place to stay. If I could get a room like this, for this price, in Europe, I wouldn‚Äôt use apartment sharing sites.

review: Despite the poor condition of the room we stayed, I am still giving this hotel 3 stars as the staff was very flexible, welcoming, and accommodating to our requests...I emailed the property about a week before and let them know about our early arrival and our need for fridge, microwave, baby crib (we were travelling with our 1 year old son). All has been met, and email communication has been prompt :) When we checked in, the staff was very welcoming and so friendly to my baby :)Good parts about the hotel :- Reasonable walking distance to Pike Place Market & Westlake Centre.(with baby in a stroller & carrier)- Friendly staff- Starbucks, Bartell Drugstore, Public Library nearby.Now the bad parts (unfortunately):- We stayed in room 314, which was near the elevator, and was VERY noisy.- I did expect our assigned room won't be in a good location as I bookedthe hotel from bidding from priceline, but this was little too much.- My husband and I travel a lot and we're (including the baby) not sensitiveto noise... so, we generally don't ask for quiet rooms. That was a bad choice.- We constantly heard sirens / car honking / people chatting outside etc (This is OK).- We also constantly heard faucet & shower running from rooms, as well asheating system constantly on and off from other rooms (Our heater was off).- I did bring these issues when we checked out, and the staff offered to take50% off from valet parking fee, which we appreciated.Overall, nice hotel for one night, but ask for higher floor & quieter room ( or bring ear plugs.....) even though you are not sensitive to noise.

review: Spartan room. No curtains, desk, chair, dresser, or decorations. Two friends traveling together so at least there were two luggage racks, but little space to hang clothes. Good for a short, two night stay. All of the pillows on the bed were super firm, Second morning, someone knocked and tried to enter around when we were still in bed. Bathroom miniscule, and no rack to hang wet towels on the wall, though there was space to add one.. The bathtub didn't drain properly so while showering, I stood in a pool of water. Friendly guy at front desk. He recommended the Crab Pot, and we were very disappointed. (Zero ambiance (a roll of paper towels for napkins). Complimentary wine reception a nice touch. The area is hilly, so be prepared for that. Walking distance to Pike's Market, and a steep 3 block uphill walk upon your return. (Recommend seeing the public library across the street; magnificent architecture.) They do include a clock with charger outlets, a coffee pot for those drinking black coffee, iron, bottles of water. Noise from street/other guests wasn't a problem.

review: This review is based solely on the first desk clerk Elsa. Who was not only rude but treated the guests like feces under her shoe.Upon arriving at the hotel, Elsa asked for the name on our reservation and for our ID and card. She turned and started to yell at this elderly gentleman that she was not accepting any cash at the moment. He walked around to the front of the desk. I assume because he couldn't hear her to which she replied. Sir, didn't I just say we are not accepting any cash. I felt bad for how she spoke to him but said nothing. As we provided her with our information, she indicated we would be charged a half for the room for one night and incidental. We explained we shouldn't have any charges other than incidentals because our reward points covered the room. She said she didn't see that in her system so she couldn't honor it. We then provided her with a copy of the confirmation email that was sent when we called Marriott to make the reservations she still said I can't do anything with that because it's not in my system. In a condescending voice, she tells us you can call Marriott and complain but not until Monday because they are closed. We took the key and went to our room. As we walked in two people were sleep in the bed. We must have scared one coming in and woke him up. We closed the door and went back down to the front desk. My mother spoke to Elsa and I called Marriott. I was able to talk with someone. He called Else to speak with her about the situation. We can overhear her speaking to the guy in the same tone that was used with us. She told him she hadn't been to the room to verify if someone was in bed, but her system said the sroom was empty (like we lied) and that her system also didn't show that our points covered the room. After she hung up, he came back on the line with me and said she will be issuing you a refund for the amount charged and changing your room. I also understand your complaint about the attitude it sounds like she may need some training. I will notate the account and request that additional compensation is provided to you all. We left asked Else to verify the conversation then went up to the new room after she gave us a new key.Thinking the problem was solved, we went to bed only to wake up to an additional charge for another night and another $10 random charge. We only stayed that one night and would be leaving for a cruise the next morning. We went down to the front desk and explained what happened. Elsa was gone by this point. Both women working the desk indicated they did not have the authority to do anything. We asked them to call the manager. She tried to say it was just a misunderstanding and brush Elsa's actions under the rug. She did pay for our cab to the port; however, the money was held on our card and not released until the end of the cruise. We spoke with the GM, who again apologized on behalf of his staff, indicated he was not aware of anything that took place, but he would like the opportunity to correct the issue if we would give them another chance. At first, we were not going to take him up on the offer but decided we would allow them to fix the problem when we returned. We needed a room for one night. Well, when we called to make arrangements, we were told the only thing they would do as a resolution was allow us to book the room at a senior discount rate. Unacceptable since we already qualify for this. If you have the chance to stay at this hotel DON'T. Find one that will give you a room without a stranger in the bed and someplace that would value you as a customer.

hotel: Fairfield Inn & Suites Miami Airport South
review: We booked this hotel for just one night in Miami and from the minute we entered the lobby, we noticed the couple in front of us arguing with the manager over room issues ..Flag #1. We proceeded to check in where the front desk lady tells me there will be a $150 hold on my card. When I said no way! She speaks to the manager and it goes to $25. They failed to mention we were being billed for parking as well.Off we go to our room only to find out the King "suite" did not have a pull out sofa as we thought. We request to switch rooms since we needed the extra bed for my oldest daughter so ended up in a double. When we return from a nice day touring Miami we settle in our new space and my nine month old who is in the crawling stage stands near the air vent 2 feet from me and suddenly starts choking! It was bad enough that we panicked and called 911 and called the front desk to do the same. Long story short, whatever choked the baby was not in her throat but she had coughed up some blood which is why we panicked. Manager came upstairs to emphasize he called 911. once he saw the baby was ok and commotion settled he left without a word. We went back in the room and I searched the floor thoroughly until I found the culprit. what appeared to be clear plastic tags. Not ours since we had nothing new and nothing near the area she choked. I went the next morning to the front desk and told the housekeeping needs to be more thorough and also told the manager I wanted a copy of the incident. He says "what incident?" I said my baby was choking bad, lips turned blue and you say nothing happened?? I was furious at that point on how he dismissed it as if since she didnt die then I guess no incident report needs to be written. he also followed it by saying I could not prove that those tags were already in the room as if defending himself from a lawsuit! Basically I wanted it for any doctor follow and to ensure that his upper management was aware. I plan to follow up with Fairfields corporate headquarters on this because I cannot believe how this "manager" dismissed a very traumatic incident in the room as nothing.Yes I can go on about the filthy outdated place and the crappy breakfast but this was so much more. He could have done many things as a manager to follow up and ensure everything was ok but he truly did not care. I cannot support a company that does not show even a bit of sympathy in such a situation for its patrons. Hope someone from upper management see this.
response: Dear Ms Lilliam,I can only imagine how upset you felt that we fell short on providing empathy to you when you most needed it. I have shared your feedback with the appropriate hotel team to ensure that this was an isolated issue that is corrected moving forward.I truly wish your daughter is doing much better and hope to have the opportunity to see you sometime in the future and provide you with the service you deserve.Best regards,Guillermo Del Sol

hotel: Fairfield Inn & Suites New York Downtown Manhattan/World Trade Center Area
review: My husband and I stayed at this new hotel for 4 nights while in New York. The hotel is new and the location is superb, however there are several points that made our stay unpleasant:1. We've booked ahead a King room. Upon arrival (at 11 pm) we were notified that there is no clean King room available. Fortunately they upgraded us to an executive double room. The room was large and everything was new.2. The floor in the room was completely covered in dirt dust and nails. It seemed as if they never cleaned the floor since construction ended. We've asked 3 times at the reception for the floor to be cleaned but they never did.2. On our 3rd day we received an e-mail notifying us that we are being checked out. Our reservation was for 4 nights. consequently we were moved to a different room.3. The second room we were moved to was nice and very cozy, however it was right next to their ice machine which made a terrible noise with people filling ice throughout the night. when you book make sure to ask for a room not near the ice machine.4. The air conditioner at that room has only 2 modes- it would either heat indefinitely (no temperature control) or when we tried to shut it down the room turned freezing. As you can imagine we slept very poorly on our last night.5. various small irritations included: there is no drawers (for clothes or whatnot) anywhere in the room except one small drawer by the bed. there is exactly zero hangers for towels which you are supposed to just throw on the floor I assume. the hallways are narrow and painted black for some reason and give a kind of drug den feel.6. There are only 2 elevators for the 26+ floors at the hotel. You have to wait a very long time for the elevator and therefore we always took the fire escape stairs.Overall we were not happy staying at this hotel and would not recommend it.
response: Thank you very much for taking the time out of your schedule to offer us some feedback about your recent stay with us at the Fairfield In and Suites by Marriott.I would like to extend my sincerest apology that we were not able to provide you with the levels of service we normally pride ourselves with.We have taken your concerns to the proper department heads to ensure we do not repeat this issues.Thank you again and we look forward to welcoming you back in the future.

hotel: Fairfield Inn & Suites New York Downtown Manhattan/World Trade Center Area
review: Overall we had a decent enough stay here. Just a quick one night in the city, so we selected based on location and price. We generally stay at Residence Inn or Courtyards and this Fairfield was a bit of step down in terms of service from those hotels. Perhaps it's just that this is such a large hotel? Here were our issues:- Room booked for two people, arrived to find ONE set of towels in the room. We both wanted to shower on arrival after a long drive and my husband (over 6 ft tall) had to dry off with a hand towel because more towels still had not been delivered an hour after our arrival and complaint. A single additional towel was delivered at some point in the evening while we were out. I can understand extra towels taking a while to deliver, but when you don't provide enough towels for the individuals booked to stay in the room the delivery should be faster.- The sink drain is unlike any I've ever seen. We were convinced it was broken! Maybe we don't get out enough, but you have to push the drain to get it to pop up. Okay - so maybe the maid should leave it in the down position? We had a gross sink of water before we got that one sorted out with the front desk.- Allow plenty of time to get your vehicle returned from valet parking. We called ahead 15 minutes before going down and still waited another 15 min or more for the car to arrive.Overall and okay stay. I hate to be picky and complain, but the towel thing really was annoying. Breakfast buffet was decent, paper plates and plastic ware, but food was okay.

review: As for the rest, I imagine it was a typical small space NYC hotel. No lobby to speak of. Limited seating, a bench to wait on. Tight spaces everywhere. It did have a nice fitness center for its size. But with the air conditioning not working in July in the hallways, lobby, and common area, it made for a tough stay. Luckily the air in the rooms worked or I would have checked out. Inconvenient to have to go to the bottom floor for a vending machine. The elevators were small and took a ridiculously long time to appear at breakfast time. The result of a 38 floor hotel with about 8 rooms on a small floor footprint. The breakfast food was great and they had everything they needed to and more, just no space to sit and uncomfortable wooden chairs and no elbow room. Look elesewhere.

review: The hotel is very near Times square and just a walk over the street to port authority bus terminal.The room we stayed in (4 adults) was to small, the room and the comfortable beds was to small, not enough space to put your luggage and jackets.The A/C when turned on is very noisy, so the other good thing is the big TV!.Breakfast was good, but the same for 2 weeks, got a little bit boring i must say.Cleaning staff and the staff when we did eat breakfast was very nice, but some of the check in staff where very unprofessional, the only positive here is that they checked you in very fast.When i checked in i was told that i had to pay the first nights room fee to ensure the reservation, i agreed and payed.After a week our room was locked, i thought it was a mistake and i contacted the check in staff.They told me that the room has been locked due to my card was declined, i thought this was a joke, because my card was not blocked (I contacted my bank later and got that confirmed), but they refused to lock our room and kept claiming that my card was declined, so i was "forced" to pay with my mastercard and losing over 30 min of my day.When asked what kind of service this was, and when told i already payed for the first night to get my stay ensured, they told me that was not the case, i had paid 200 dollars to ensure the reservation.They told me that was their policy, i told them, so the policy is to lock your costumers from their rooms with false claims? They did not answer, but said that i must not think that they would fool me, but that was exactly how i felt and told them so.They could have put a note on my door, or in my room to contact the reception, knock on my door or call when i was back in my room, this was a very rude way to treat your costumers, i have never experienced this kind of behavior anywhere in the world.I would chose this hotel for its location, and not chose it for the some rude check in staff, your choice.

review: During our LA visit we spent 4 nights at this cool little hotel. I travel with a family so I have 2 small kids (9 & 11) I wanted to try something a little more personal by staying at a 'boutique' hotel rather then big chain hotels. But unfortunately I didn't feel the personal touch that I thought you would get and It wasn't like I was saving money by staying here. Location was fabulous!! With the Grove across the road, you certainly have everything at your door step. It does have cool little things, like the bikes and books and pool with rubber duckies and 2 cute little budgies in the lobby!! It's clean, safe and a very good looking place. Room I was in was kind of out under a stair case, so no sunlight shining my room, but you can sit out on the balcony if you wanted. Does have a restaurant TART in house, so that was cool. I feel bad saying this as I have worked in hospitality before and I know it can be challenging but I feel that could have been managed better. Overall I guess I was chasing some welcoming customer service. I love the USA and I love its people and I kind of wasn't feeling it here. Just a greeting when I walk through the lobby would have made me happy. I don't want to waited on hand and foot I just wanted the odd smile. As I was leaving though I did come across Bryan at reception and five stars would go to him. In my brief conversation with him, it made my view on my stay lift a few levels ... So thank you to him. Customer Service is the key.
response: Thank you for taking the time out of your schedule to respond to our survey. It is greatly appreciated. We do read each of these and learn from them.Everyone one of our employees should have smiled and said hello what you experienced is not our normal operation.we wish you the safest and best travelsEllen and Peter

review: Where do I start?We arrived to find it is car valet parking only - another expense on an already quite expensive hotel. I feel it should be free parking or at least advertise the parking ratesWe chose this one because of its apparent close proximity to the Merrick Quarter - but when we arrived there were no maps in English in reception, and the girl in Reception did not have particularly good English.We went up to the rooftop pool - it was not heated and the bar there was not open.At no time were we told where breakfast is served, how much it cost, or what time.The following morning we found out about the free trolley buses that run to the Miracle Mile, but were ot told how frequent they were or the exact route, and noone on them spoke English.We tried finding Merrick's buildings of architectural interest but despite the fact they were supposed to be close could not find them.The hotel is not located in the best of areas either (lots of small industrial units, selling and repairing cars for example). hotel: Four Points by Sheraton Coral Gables
review: The staff couldn't have been nicer, but there were some minor annoyances that marred the trip a bit. I would stay there again though. The rooms were clean and comfortable, and the food was good. So, here are the annoyances: Biggest - I received a fraud alert "card not present" transaction while at a UM football game. It was for an odd-amount transaction at a Best Western in Fort Lauderdale. I called and cancelled my credit card only to later learn that the owner of the Four Points also owned a Best Western and was for some reason running charges through its other hotel. More minor but still annoying: We stayed three nights. Our room was cleaned each day but our coffee inexplicably never replaced. We went down to the lobby for coffee, but the only creamers were nauseating flavored ones and no milk or non-flavored creamers. We told the front desk the first morning, but each morning there were still only flavored creamers in the lobby. Finally, on the last morning, we asked to have plain creamers delivered to our room. A housekeeper (also very nice) arrived with towels. I don't know why. When we asked her for plain creamers, she did eventually return with both coffee and creamers. The final minor annoyance was that there was an 18% gratuity added to everything at the restaurant, even the breakfast buffet. But then there was also a separate and addition tip line, leaving you to wonder if the 18% was actually going to the servers or not, which was just awkward. So enough complaining - the hotel was generally fine. I would easily have given them four stars with a few adjustments.
response: Thank you for taking the time to share your comments. We are delighted to hear that you enjoyed the comfort of the hotel and the guestroom. hotel: Four Points by Sheraton Manhattan SoHo Village
review: My wife and I chose this hotel as a last minute option on a whim because we wanted to hang out in Manhattan over the weekend. We actually used the app Hotel Tonight and on that app, their users rated it at 87%, so we figured, it'll suffice. We only booked a 1 night stay but in just 1 night, we came to the realization we should've spent a bit more money and could've avoided possibly one of our worst stays in hotels ever! Now, don't get me wrong, we didn't book this hotel expecting a boutique experience, but there are just some things we have complaints about that shouldn't be present in ANY traveler's experience regardless of the $$ bracket of hotel. List is as follows:1. NOISY hallways/rooms...If you cherish quiet and sound, consistent sleep, DO NOT STAY HERE!2. Uncomfortable beds...if you have even the slightest back problems, pregnant or are used to a nice, comfy bed, DO NOT STAY HERE! (The seats in my car are more comfortable than the queen bed in our room was, no joke!)3. Scratchy sheets...if you love slipping into a bed with sheets thread count >200 DO NOT STAY HERE! I swear the thread count on these sheets were 30..we could've used cardboard box panels and that would've felt smoother.4. Lobby bar does NOT sell water bottles....they offer 1 complimentary bottle of water with your stay & that would be fine if traveling solo, however, it was my wife & I staying there, so when we ran out of that, we went to the lobby bar to buy another bottle but they told my PREGNANT wife that they don't sell bottled water.. WTH! Love someone to explain that one to me. DO NOT STAY HERE!5. Cleaning staff too loud in the morning for turning rooms around...check out time is at noon and while that's pretty standard for any hotel, if you've read all the above grievances, you're expecting to sleep until pretty much 11am at latest. NOPE, not in this hotel! The cleaning staff must have been trained by paramilitary assault troops because at 9am it felt like the SS Troops were hollering and banging through rooms and the hallways waking you up (if you even were asleep still at 9am in the first place) DO NOT STAY HERE!6. Pillows are like flapjacks FLAT...Ever had to sleep on the floor without a pillow? Ever fall asleep on your desk pulling all nighters for college and your neck hurts because you didn't have a pillow? This is pretty much what you can expect of the pillow selection at this hotel. When you walk in the room, the bed has like 8 pillows on a queen size bed, but its a moot point if all of them are as flat as bar codes. DO NOT STAY HERE!7. Air Con unit leaks water...the entire time we had the A/C unit on or the Heat on the system leaked water onto the carpet below. Since the room is already a small fit for that queen size bed, one MUST walk directly by that leaking A/C unit so unless you keep your shoes on inside the room, you're pretty much playing in puddles by the window not to mention what mildew must grow in that room daily! DO NOT STAY HERE!
response: Hello there,Thank you for taking the time to complete a review in regards to your recent stay at the Four Points by Sheraton Manhattan SoHo Village.As we pride ourselves on delivering a memorable hotel experience during your travels, we have unfortunately fallen short of our goal during your recent stay. hotel: Four Points by Sheraton Manhattan SoHo Village
review: I recently stayed at this property for 3 weekend nights, in a two-queen-bed room. The front desk, cleaning and restaurant staff were very pleasant, and I felt that had I had any special requests, they probably would have helped me out. As for the property itself, it is a reasonable value if you are getting a decent rate. The room was as small as I expected for a NYC hotel room, with a worse view than expected (of an alleyway). The fan was extremely loud, but worked to effectively block any and all noise. The beds were very comfortable and there were plenty of outlets. The bathroom was very, very small, with a counter that wouldn't fit much on it and an odd faucet setup that made it virtually impossible to wash one's face without getting water everywhere. But, the water pressure was excellent -- better than home! There are only two elevators, which often meant a bit of a wait. The lobby gets cramped easily during popular check in and check out times. The fitness centre has good equipment, but not much of it; however, I didn't really see more than one person there at any given time, so probably not an issue. Most importantly, the hotel was very well located -- several subway stops nearby, an easy walk to Soho, Tribeca, the Financial District and Midtown.
response: Dear exiledsuburban,Thank you for your honest feedback! We're glad that you enjoyed our location and staff service. The comments has been passed on to our appropriate departments to take immediate actions on the things that we fell short on.Whenever your travel brings you to Soho, we'll be expecting your arrival to our hotel. Thank you once again for choosing us!Best Regards,Patricia CarusoGeneral ManagerPhone : 212 229 9988Email : Patricia.caruso@fourpointssohonyc.com
responder: Response from patricis c, General Manager at Four Points by Sheraton Manhattan SoHo Village

response: Dear Rajan Awwargal,Thank you for taking the time to write a review and for sharing your comments.I am very sorry to hear the stay did not meet your expectations nor were we able to gain your trust.I have taken the feedback seriously, as normally our teams do work at their best and are highly commended by the majority of our guests.In order to address your concerns I would like to take this opportunity to share with you that the Four Points Brand does not require microwaves or mini fridges in the guest rooms. hotel: Four Points by Sheraton Midtown - Times Square
review: We basically selected this hotel out of our options through SPG due to location. It is in excellent proximity to Theatre Row and Times Square, and none of the subways are more than a 5 minute walk. That being said, the room with two double beds was cramped. We opted for the non-daily room service and when it was cleaned, the only difference was the beds were made and we got new towels. I couldn't even tell the room had been picked up. On top of that the trash can was left outside for us to put back in. The television hardly worked, it was a 50-50 shot if you wanted to watch anything. Luckily, we didn't spend much time in the room, but if we did, it would have been frustrating. The lack of 24 hour room service was annoying as well. For a city that never sleeps, we had to take our business elsewhere when we were hungry after shows knowing the hotel would have likely been more convenient, but was not an option.The ONLY reason I'd stay there again, is for the location. Even so I'd venture to guess the Mariott might be worth the extra money.
response: Dear Amanda,I am so happy to read that you enjoyed our location. We are always happy when our guests can take advantage of the convenience of being so close to all that Midtown NYC has to offer.In regard to the other elements of your stay that were not as great, I do apologize. I will deliver this feedback to my housekeeping department regarding the level of cleaning of your room, and the garbage can being left out.Thank you for letting me know about the TV, I do apologize for that as well. This is something I will ensure my Housekeeping team is testing when they clean each room to ensure it is working properly.Lastly, I am sorry that the lack of room service was frustrating. Room service is very convenient, and though we do not offer this feature, if our bistro is open at that time, you can always order, and have your food put in a to-go container to take up to your room with you.Thank you for providing us your feedback.
responder: Response from Corey C, Manager at Four Points by Sheraton Midtown - Times Square

review: Recently stayed here over July 4th week with my wife and we were disappointed overall, specifically about room. Front house staff was very nice. It Wasn't what we expected for room accomodation especially for a Sheraton in Times Square. I asked and they saud all rooms are same size except for suites. It was very small compared to most all hotels we've stayed at world wide. The Bathroom was very small, shower door was a pain getting in/out, no bathroom fan, No mini fridge or microwave in rooms, so we had to request a fridge which thankfully they gave us one to keep our doggy bags of food and drinks cold. The room Tstat didnt work so ran 24/7 and didnt really get as cold as we like it at night. Told maintenance man but never looked at. Only one of two elevator seemed to be working everytime we used it, which was an issue being on 16 floor and cant walk stairs. The restaurant was only avg for breakfast and pricy; $18.99 buffet with limited selection of hot foods, ala cart $3.99 for toast, $5.99 for cold cereal, $4.99 for 4 slices of bacon. The location is great and convenient to subway and Times Square. The bed was excellent! Dont think we will be back.

hotel: Four Points by Sheraton New York Downtown
review: It all started at check-in. After flying in from Texas, we arrived earlier than the 3:00 pm check-in time. We were told to come back at 3 and our room would be ready. Well at 4:00 pm, we were finally given a key to our room. We had 4 people in our party but we're given only 1 key. When asked the clerk said they were waiting on a key order and would have some in a few hours.The room was booked for 5 nights on Booking.com. As such,when I tried to add my Marriott Rewards at check in, I was told our stay didn't qualify because it was booked through a third party. WHAT?? That's plain ridiculous. We had ordered extra towels which were not furnished so we had to ask for them again each day.The air conditioner was broken(bad thermostat) and they said they would have engineering look at it. Well, it was never fixed and all they did was try to educate me on how HVAC systems work. We roasted for 4 days...very uncomfortable.The shower head was broken and the shower wouldn't drain. Again they were informed but failed to rectify the problem. The conditioner dispenser was refilled after we complained, but was not working so nothing would dispensed.No microwave, no fridge and lighting was less than adequate.On the plus side, free bottled water each day.You have many choices for a stay downtown, so you would think they would go an extra mile to earn your business...not in this case. Very disappointed in the property while at the same time the staff were pleasant. Be careful, a bargain may be more than a bargain!

review: I felt cheated and mislead. I paid for a PREMIUM King Hotel Room. The room was INSANELY small, dark, and cramped‚Äîwithout a single creature comfort. Not even a plastic cup in the bathroom (no room for one!). The ‚Äúcouch‚Äù was two wooden bench seats pushed together, and crammed between the bed and the wall.I questioned my reservation, and the clerk even acknowledged that all the rooms are the same size.This property should NOT be allowed to call itself a hotel or to advertise premium rooms. response: Thank you for your feedback. We're very sorry to hear that you did not find your stay at our hotel to be comfortable. review: I stayed at Freehand having moved from Found Hotel after 2 very strong recommendations that it was THE place to be. I was really disappointed. The 4 bed dorms are small. There's no room for luggage which means it's left strewn across the floor. If you're on an upper floor, get used to taking the stairs because the elevators are slow. There's no "hostel" vibe because the bar and coffee shop are both open to the general public and there's no hostel only space to relax in beyond the kitchen so it's difficult to meet other travellers. Had the unfortunate event of having both mine and my friends food stolen from the communal fridge by another guest. It was in the fridge less than 9 hours before someone ate it and upon informing staff, were told we use the fridge at our own risk. No signs deterring guests from taking good not belonging to them. No labelling system to clearly state who's food belongs to whom. Just 3 fridges with separate dates stating the dates and times of when the fridge will be emptied by cleaning staff. This place isn't a hostel and doesn't share or encourage the hostel spirit, it's a budget hotel with shared rooms.The continental breakfast they speak of is toast, condiments and cereal. Housekeeping comes at 10am and Wales the room despite checkout being at 12pm. I had weird interactions with them about other guests not being out on time and had to remind them checkout wasn't for another few hours.As far as positives, the location is very good, some of the staff were nice, the beds do have small privacy curtains and lamps which is nice but no plug sockets.After a disappointing stay, we awoke on our final day to find the building had no water and we were hours from boarding a flight. Not something the hotel can control but the final straw for us. It was cheaper than Found Hotel but I'd definitely pay the extra for a much better and happier experience. If you're in the city to party for one night, it's good enough to just lay your head and go home.
response: Hello!I am sorry to hear your experience was not what you expected and very far from it. We appreciate your feedback and will share this with our team in hopes to better accommodate our future guests. Our rooms are purposely on the cozier side to encourage guests to get out of their rooms and explore the public areas of the hotel and city. I am sorry to hear your food was taken out of the public fridge and the uncontrollable water outage your experienced. I hope that you will choose to stay again in the near future so we can turn this experience you had around! As always thank you for choosing Freehand Chicago!
responder: Response from FreehandCHI, Manager at Freehand Chicago

review: We were not familiar with Best Western but thought the Plus would be nice. We should have had lowered expectations, but here are the facts.First Impressions:Small lobby and not the newest of hotels. The staff was nice at check-in. Two computers and a tv in the lobby. Our hope was that the room would be nicer than the lobby.Check-in:You received a parking pass, wi-fi code, map of the area, keys, 20% off coupon for IHOP(lunch and dinner), and instructions for the shuttle that takes you close to the pier and promenade for free. They is a $25 per day incidental fee that is refunded if you don't use any of the pay for use services(they did not mention until I asked at check out).To the room:You key must be used to get to your floor. There are vending machines and an ice machine on each floor by the elevator. The rooms are okay. The sink is separate from the shower and toilet. The tv is flat screen and there is a fridge(ours would not close). They gave us two complimentary bottles of water. No carpet in the rooms which made it seem more like a two star. The mattress was extremely comfortable.The staff:We had to have our linens changed upon arrival and the bathroom "re-cleaned"(blue soap residue from previous guest). The good thing to say is they were quick to fix and apologetic. They try and meet your request and fulfill their obligations(shuttle driver was a no show so they paid for a cab).We say we would stay there again as it was about $500 for two nights and included parking but I would prefer another hotel that had a few more amenities.

review: Really wanted to like this hotel but it fell short in a couple of areas for me. As other reviews indicate it is a smallish boutique style hotel at the end of the strip on Sunset. Recently updated it has a small pool area which is surrounded on three sides by the hotel rooms. The bar and reception are well decorated and the reception and bell staff are pleasant. The small issues I had were with the amount of noise ( from other guests admittedly) that you can hear from adjoining rooms on the same floor, and above and below you - we were disturbed on a couple of nights well into the small hours as folk returned to the hotel. The valet service if you have a car is steep at $40 per night although the guys are pretty efficient. Outside happy hour the drinks are expensive too which means we did not eat or dine at the hotel as there is much better value out on the strip. The restaurant rarely had any diners when we were there (5days) so that was either price or quality I guess? These issues might be common on the strip but I am sure there are better value hotels should we revisit. And finally I found a couple of the guys behind the bar a little surly and looking to favour the big tippers - disappointing but natural I guess. Would we stay here again - probably not, a little cliched, a little expensive and I think there would be better options elsewhere.
response: We appreciate you taking time to let us know of your experience. We are disappointed to hear that you felt the pool area is small because the Grafton has the largest pool on the strip. I apologize if you felt the bartenders to be a bit surly as that is not our goal because we pride ourselves in providing genuine service to all our guests. We are also sorry if you felt our restaurant was too expensive. Oliver‚Äôs Prime is a boutique steakhouse and is priced very competitive with restaurants in the West Hollywood area. Chef Greg Elkin provides an excellent product and our restaurant has been recognized as a great choice for diners. We hope that you enjoyed your visit to the West Hollywood area.

review: We have stayed at a Hyatt House in Frisco, Texas and had a great experience and we expected the same from this Houston trip. Overall the suite was clean and in decent shape, housekeeping did a great job daily. The bartender on Friday night was fun and very friendly as well.Apparently this hotel has turned into a base for FEMA recipients which really isn't the issue. The issue was that management isn't doing anything to keep up the hotel standards. People lounging in the halls, kids running up and down hallways yelling and the big issue for us was the parking garage. There were people hanging out in the gated garage day and night, we would pull in looking for a space in the evening and there were literally women laying in the spaces spread out like it was a beach. At that point we didn't know there were people staying long term from the hurricane and wondered if they were sneaking in past the gates but a staff member told us the hotel was no longer really a business hotel and had become "hell" over the past month or so. The garage reeked like cigarettes since there were ALWAYS multiple people lounging around out there smoking (cigarettes and weed) and there were burning cigarettes left right outside the door leading inside. It irks me to no end Hyatt charged $16 for self parking and my spouse wasn't even comfortable with my walking to the car alone to get something. review: Booked this property as is a reputable name and they offered a cruise and stay package. The property itself is easy to find, the rooms are comfortable, and in a good location with dining options within walking distance and the Coconut Grove district very close as well. What we found lacking was the serviceand knowledge by the front desk team. The shuttle to the cruise port was late, and it seemed no one had any answers as to when it would arrive. I had booked an early boarding pass, and was assured by the front desk that the shuttle was always on time, and usually very early, so I did not make other arrangements to get to the port.On the day of the cruise, we were sitting outside waiting for the shuttle only to find out that we did not receive a required form saying we could get on the shuttle. When I went in to ask about the form, they gave me a handwritten version since they had run out of the normal ones. Of course, the gentleman who was gathering the information prior to the shuttle's arrival did not want to accept that. We had to stand in line and speak to the hotel management who assured the gentleman that it was OK. However, apparently they had grossly over booked the shuttle. We saw other cruise goers call Uber to come and pick them up.... To the hotel's credit, at my request they did arrange for a cab to come and get us so we could get to the port only an hour late... it was frustrating that there was absolutely no coordination with the transportation company.For a property that has been running this package for a long time it seemed wildly unorganized; the hotel staff was not at all apologetic about the situation. I get it that they were not the shuttle operators, but when offering the package it seems there ought to be some ownership.All in all, I think it was still a good value. If your cruise boarding time is early, I would perhaps explore other options. If we had a late boarding time and/or things had run smoothly with the shuttle operator, would have likely been an exceptional experience.
response: Dear Jodi M,Thank you for taking the time to provide us with your feedback. I apologize for the late response, I can only imagine the frustration trying to get to the port early and finding the inconvenience of not being able to board the shuttle. review: When I pulled up to the Hampton on Queen Anne, the building was covered in scaffolding and the construction use sign was unreadable due to graffiti. I wasn‚Äôt sure if the place was open, but a construction worker encouraged me to walk through the door. The Hampton is undergoing a remodel. The building that houses the one-bedroom suites is completely closed for renovation, but the one with hotel rooms is not. The fitness center was not open. The breakfast lounge area is open even though it is in the midst of changes.There is construction going on across the street, unrelated to the Hampton, and not under their control. But the rumble of the trucks and other heavy equipment was so loud that I immediately asked staff to move me to another part of the building. Which they did. That room had a view only of scaffolding, with fire resistant covering to block light, but it was quiet. The bed was comfortable, and the shower hot. I got a good night‚Äôs sleep, which is what one expects of a hotel. However, I do expect a warning about remodeling. I never received anything in the mail and the Hilton website doesn‚Äôt mention the construction.The staff were super friendly and as accommodating as they could be under the circumstances. If not for them, I might have switched hotels. The Hampton is typically reliable, no matter the location, so I‚Äôll try them again AFTER the remodel is complete. Staff expects most of it to be done by March. By that time, the construction zone across the street will not be as much of a issue.Please note that my rating is due to the inconvenience of the remodeling, the construction noise from the street, and the lack of usable window in the room due to scaffolding. These issues are temporary. To be fair, you should call the hotel and get a status report.

review: Am almost one year removed from my stay, which was in May 2012. Booked @ the HI b/c it was new, well-ranked on this site & b/c I was using hhonors points for my first night. Arrived early and was told that the only available double rooms were accessible rooms, so I took one - as I just wanted to unwind from my traveling. Room was small, but appropriately furnished. Bathroom seemed institutional. Breakfast was just ok - nothing to write home about. Pool was just ok as well. Perhaps a theme is emerging....Was in MIA for a 3-day weekend. The next morning, after being hassled @ the front desk about receiving the govt contractor rate I reserved for the balance of my stay (& for which I qualified), I jumped ship and went to the Epic - which was admittedly more than the govt rate @ the HI, but was comparable to its prevailing room rates.Upon my arrival @ the Epic, I knew I'd selected the right spot!. The lobby is open, airy & breezy, and projects a distinct feeling and ambiance of being "someplace more than no place." Received an upgraded room w/ balcony overlooking the hotel's pool and the bay. The room's furnishings were sumptuous, the bathroom lavishly appointed, & the pool area felt resort-like. The staff were courteous and service-oriented. Instead of simply obtaining lodging, @ the Epic I enjoyed a 5 star experience.Would encourage travelers considering the HI to instead search hard for a good rate @ a premium property. It's well worth experiencing VIP treatment during your short stay in MIA.

review: First of all I have to say that the service here was outstanding, from the time of check-in to checkout. The concierge was very helpful with all our questions while constantly maintaining a pleasant smile. The hotel was very clean and updated with a nice firm bed. The hotel is located in a very convenient location just a short walk to the metromover. Since we were there for a basketball game at the arena, this couldn't have worked out any better as the metromover takes you within a few blocks of the arena. We checked out early in the morning so I really can't comment on the breakfast.Now for the disappointing.. We pulled our car up to the front door of the hotel for check-in which is on the 6th floor. This was no problem as I had previously read on tripadvisor of the location of check in. The hotel has a parking garage for guests which costs $18 per night. No problem with this either as parking can be very difficult in Miami. The problem was getting to the garage. As I said we pulled the car up to the front lobby for check-in and then went back to the car to park. As soon as we pulled out, immediately next to the hotel is a parking lot entrance. We pulled in and noticed our keycard did not work so we talked into the call box and said we just checked in and our keycard didn't work. The gate opened and we parked the car. We found our way to the elevator and was somewhat confused as our keycard did not work in the elevator. Fortunately, there were other people on the elevator and we asked if we were at the Hampton since the floor numbers on the elevator seemed a little strange. We were told no so that explained why our cards didn't work. We left the parking lot and drove around to get back to the hotel, and low and behold, the parking lot entrance for the hotel is located just before pulling the car up to the front lobby. In other words, when facing the hotel, parking is to the right.One of the major disappointments of the hotel was the noise level in the room. I know there are many inconsiderate people who spend the night in a hotel and they can be extremely noisy if they hold their conversations in the hallway while people are trying to sleep. Slamming their doors is also another inherent characteristic of these people. It seemed that there was very little soundproofing throughout the room to deaden the noise level as the sound just echoes throughout the halls.If we return to the Miami area for another outing, we would probably stay at the hotel again because of its convenience, even with all the issues. However, I would definitely complain to the staff this time if there were some very annoying and disturbing people disrupting the guests.
