review: Overall, I'd say this hotel is average to above average. I will say that I'm stunned that so many reviewers before me gave it 5 out of 5.It's been a while (decades) since I last drove into Manhattan, so I was a little nervous about getting to the hotel, unloading bags, parking, etc. When we pulled up, there were about 2-3 spots right out front, which surprised me. It gave my mother (the person who booked the trip) a chance to run in and talk to the front desk attendant, and I didn't have to stress about being double-parked. That was a bonus.The hotel works in conjunction with two local garages to offer discounted parking for guests, which is helpful. Still expensive to park for 1-2 days (it's Manhattan, after all), but it's not of control. It cost $70 (total) for 2 days in the Rockefeller Center parking garage, which is a relatively short walk from the hotel.We had originally booked what I believe was a 2-bedroom suite (or something along those lines). There was an issue that prohibited them from giving us that type of room when we arrived, so they offered two separate rooms for the same price, which we took. We had to wait a little bit to get in (We walked around a little), but they did have us in before regular check-in time, which was appreciated.We were initially given 1208 and 1211. Only 1208 was ready. OMG. In my opinion, and I'm not over-the-top picky, this room was small and dated. We were stunned, and not in a good way, because this room looked nothing like the pics we had seen online. Wow. The door for 1211 was open as well, and although it appeared to be a bigger room, it was still not what we were expecting. All of this was addressed at the front desk, and they did offer to move us to 704 and 706. Again, this was appreciated, and the difference between these rooms and 1208/1211, was very noticeable. The rooms on the 7th floor (the ones we saw), were way more up-to-date, including the kitchen areas.The beds were comfortable, and the rooms were relatively clean. No issues to speak of on that front. It was weird because, while it was obvious that money had been spent to upgrade the kitchen and bath areas, the bedding, walls, phones, etc., are in need of a serious upgrade. The thermostat situation was odd as well, mainly because there isn't one to be found. I spent 15 minutes looking for a thermostat in 704, and finally gave up. I opened the window to get some fresh air. There was a window unit (AC) in 1208, but not in either of the 7th floor rooms.It's a minor thing, but elevators are extremely tiny. Barely enough room for one luggage cart and 1-2 adults. They're slow too, and I ended up walking up and down the stairs on multiple occasions, rather than wait.The best thing this hotel offers is its location. I mean, it's a 10+. If you make a right and walk 2/3 of a block, you're at Rockefeller Center/Magnolia Bakery/Radio City. If you make a left and walk 1/3 of a block, you're in the heart of Times Square. It's tough to beat the location. The rest of my group went to a show at Winter Garden Theatre, and it's a 3-minute walk, at least to the 7th Avenue side.Check in/check out seemed to go smoothly, but I wasn't as involved in those processes.If I could give it a 3.5, I would, but I can't, so 3 it is. If you want something relatively clean and comfortable, and close to most touristy things in midtown, it's a good option. You do pay for that proximity (again, it's Manhattan). My advice to the hotel: please update your linens, bedding, etc. Spruce those rooms up a little.
response: Thank you so very much for letting us know about your stay by reviewing us. It really means so much to hear what our clients have to say. Apologies for any inconvenience you had during your stay with us. We always do our best to make your stay a pleasant experience. We hope you enjoyed your stay with us.
responder: Response from Radio City Apar... I, Guest Relations Manager at Radio City Apartments

review: Can‚Äôt fault the location of this hotel.... the compliments end here! The room is dated and needs desperately updating. The key cards wipe themselves regularly meaning you have to go back to reception in the slowest and unfit for the volume of customers lifts. These 2 lifts are very slow and when another customer waiting enquired as to why they were told they regularly shut one lift for the maintenance crew to use. With 26 floors of people and one lift this is ridiculous! Today our room wasn‚Äôt cleaned and first thing they do is try and blame us for having a do not disturb sign up..... we did not! The housekeeping supervisor admitted she didn‚Äôt know why it wasn‚Äôt cleaned. Finally to ice the cake they have charged and taken ¬£1400 from our credit card. I spoke to 2 different reception team who said they would consult with a manager and get back to me. Finally I spoke to a 3rd after nothing was done and said we should of read what we signed when we arrived ( we signed a check in sheet with the nightly rate printed on it but nothing to say we were paying anything) We asked for copies of what we signed but their computer system can‚Äôt print things like that! We were not informed any time that a charge was being taken (we booked and paid through Expedia) and only found out when our credit card was declined. review: I stayed here with my daughter on Jan 24, 2015 for one night for the Garth Brooks concert. The hotel is a short walk from two T stops and is in a great area especially for Boston's growing restaurant scene. The check-in process was easy and pleasant. The first room we were given was on the second floor. It was a king suite, which was a very large, well-appointed room and sitting area. Soon after, we were greeted with the noise of the guests in the room next to ours having a conversation that felt as though they were sitting in our room. We thought it was just a fluke and maybe we had some very loud talkers so we called down to the front desk. We explained the situation and they gladly moved us to the 3rd floor. We once again were very pleased with the room. After coming back from dinner and the concert, we proceeded to hear the couple in the room next to ours for hours. Needless to say, we did not sleep well. While I would love to recommend this hotel with its lovely location, decor, cleanliness, and staff...if you are looking for a good night's rest and you happen to have people next door to your room you will not have a good night's sleep.
response: We appreciate your comments regarding the great staff service you received, cleanliness of the hotel and our neat decor.We were disappointed, however, to hear of the challenges you experienced with noise from adjacent guest rooms - based on your comments we are looking into the matter and will do our very best to ensure that no guests experience the same challenge in the future.We thank you for having chosen our Residence Inn and do hope you will give us another try when in the Boston area again.
responder: Response from Steven B, General Manager at Residence Inn Boston Downtown/Seaport

review: First the good news, This hotel is beautiful. An old brick warehouse modernized but leaving a lot of the old elements. Rooms are huge with a separate living room and bedroom (but open to each other , no separate wall). Staff for the most part was great and you get a free breakfast. Now the bad, while the hotel is beautiful, some basic building aspects appear to have been skimped on. Our room was on the top floor (6th) and faced an alley. So no view but more important even though we were on the top floor we could clearly hear all the garbage trucks picking up , it was like we were right there with them. In addition there appears to be little or no insulation between the ceiling and the roof as we could hear sea gulls walking across every day. Be aware the location is a long way away from all the downtown sites, so prepare for a long walk. Speaking of, one day we had a food tour and walked many miles in 90 degree heat only to arrive back at the hotel in late afternoon to find our rooms had not been cleaned. I had to search the halls for a cleaning staff member to give us some fresh towels, Said staff member was friendly but spoke not one word of English so even though I told her we were going to take a nap, 1/2 hour later she was knocking on our door to clean it, at 5:30PM? And that free breakfast, basic at best so you get what you pay for. All in all a nice place if you have business in the Seaport area otherwise much nicer hotels closer to the action.

review: We had previously stayed at the Residence Inn by Marriott back in January 2015 for 3 weeks. Our experience in 2015 was outstanding and we had fond memories associated with staying there, so when planning our next trip to New York City for December 2016 we didn't have to think twice on where to stay. Our fond memories and feelings of this accomodation fell well short of everything we imagined it could be. It is safe to say that all our troubles began the moment we checked in with hostile and unfriendly staff at the desk, not even bothering to glance up at us to warmly welcome us. Our room was not ready for a 'couple of hours', it was a little after 1pm at this point in time. By the time we arrived later at 5pm our room was finally ready! My partner and I had requested a specific room type that was booked online according to images and description, obviously costing a lot more than the standard room. We did not receive a room that matched the description or photos that they included on their website. When this was communicated to an employee I said that this is considered false and deceptive advertising and he agreed! We communicated this to other staff at the desk but the issues we were experiencing went unresolved. We spoke with the reservation team on the phone at least twice and also approached reception twice. We were given the repeated line that the hotel's itinerary was undergoing an update because we had checked availability of the room we sought (and not received) and found several vacancies. This ultimately left us upset and confused that the room we had paid for was still available but we had not been given it. After also having contact with the 'manager' who was unhelpful and did not seem to understand our issues we finally went downstairs again for a third visit to a staff member in person. It took this many times to finally get our issue resolved, this staff member was the only employee to treat us with the upmost respect and kindness to ensure we were comfortable, happy and satisfied with our stay. As a result of all the trouble we went through, we checked out the very next day, even though we had a two week long stay that was prepaid. We have never been disrespected, treated this poorly or spoken down to before. It took far too many times finally have our feelings and thoughts understood correctly. We repeat that this was at the exception of only one employee there, because it is clear that everyone else we dealt with need a refresher on their customer service skills, and basic manners. To anyone reading this, yes it has great location near Times Square but you're wasting your time to book here. If you have any issues, I wish you luck in having them resolved, as they will fall upon deaf ears. In our experience, this hotel will not cater to even the simplest requests. It is safe to say we will not be staying here ever again.NB. A rating needs to be included but if I could, I would put 0/5.

We look forward to welcoming you back soon!Yours sincerely,Charles WeedHotel Manager

review: When we checked in we were told it would be an additional half hour for our room because it was left a "hot mess." We waited a full hour and I went up to the desk and asked what the deal was, we had been traveling several hours and wanted to cool off in the pool. After some himming and hoing they said they had the room in a handicapped version and that could be ready in five more minutes. We did get that room. The room was clean but the pull out couch was awful and the bedding was not in the closet where it was supposed to be so we had to call. We had to leave early and the "free" breakfast isn't until 6 or 7 (don't remember which), so keep that in mind if you are leaving early. The pool was very nice and so was the bar. The beds were also nice with down comforters.The next morning when we checked out I asked for some compensation for our "hour" wait. The room was not that cheap and I felt we deserved something. The desk person said she couldn't do anything until her "manager" came in and that was not until noon. I told her I had an early flight and would be long gone. After some more himming and hoing she gave us a free parking pass, so I guess they gave us the $19 in parking free...well whoopee and I had to ask for it, they offered nothing, I don't even think they said sorry. Will never stay there again. I think they overbook as I saw "several" people waiting for their room in the lobby and we checked in an hour later than check in time so their rooms were really late. Their check out time is noon, maybe they should make it 11. Nothing annoys me more than not being able to check in after a hot day of traveling. I expected more and got less.

On arrival I explained this to the clerk and asked her to amend the rate to the 159 rate on my original booking. I also explained that TripAdvisor‚Äôs rate was $152. She told me that it‚Äôs always best to book on another website to get a lower rate. Lowest Rate guarantee?? She didn‚Äôt get it so I thought I‚Äôd straighten that out with management in the morning. The next day the supervisor apologized and said he could adjust the rate for nights going forward but he couldn‚Äôt do anything for nights already billed at the higher rate.Bottom line: called Bonvoy and they‚Äôll get back to me in 5 days. I was told in the future (if there is one with this chain) don‚Äôt use the ‚Äúmodify‚Äù icon on an existing reservation. Do a separate booking for that extra night. By the way - the Bonvoy rep said their site IS the lowest and you can file a complaint on the site if you find a lower rate elsewhere. I tried that but it didn‚Äôt work. Well - I‚Äôm sure once my 5 days in purgatory is up they‚Äôll make this right. What a...relief??

hotel: Sheraton Miami Airport Hotel & Executive Meeting Center
review: First the good, we stayed here due to an overnight layover in Miami, and this hotel could not be more convenient if it tried. In fact, I would say the only good things about this hotel are all based on it‚Äôs location. If all you care about is proximity to the airport, this is your spot. The property sits as the first building outside of the airport and has a free shuttle that comes every 15 minutes or so, both pickup and drop off were easy and timely, and again VERY speedy. It also sits across the street from one of the airport train‚Äôs stops. So, it‚Äôs no surprise that most of the other guests seemed to be pilots and crew and/or families getting ready or returning from cruises. Otherwise, our experience was a mixed bag of mostly weirdness/disappointment.Check-in was efficient, and the staff was friendly, and we were even informed we‚Äôd been upgraded to their ‚Äúnicest room,‚Äù a two story suite. Our excitement quickly abated when we entered the room. It‚Äôs true this was a two-story room, but it was super awkward. You could enter from the hallway of either of two floors, downstairs had a TV, and then mismatched chairs, no couch. The bathroom on this floor was actually nicer than the one in the bedroom, as it had a vent fan, while upstairs did not. To get upstairs, your choices were to exit, and go up a floor and reenter, or take a spiral staircase that legitimately had us worried about its structure up to the lofted bedroom. Now even if this had been a magnificent stair case, it‚Äôs spiral nature would have made moving bags from floor to floor difficult at best from within the suite.The upstairs bedroom was fine enough, but again the bathroom was worse than the living area bathroom, and there was no seating besides the bed. What should have been the suite‚Äôs showcase, a two floor window out onto the golf course and canal, was in serious need of replacement/upgrade as it was molded/fogged over for most of it‚Äôs area. In short the room felt more like a weird 1970‚Äôs mountain motel than ‚Äúthe best room we have.‚ÄùEating opportunities were also a disappointment. The lounge was actually wonderful, which I think is an underrated aspect of even US-based Sheratons. Plenty of drinks to pick up and a solid breakfast. Dinner however was a different story. The lobby has two restaurants although it was hard to tell if either was open. We sat at the bar and they gave us menus for both, which were strangely very similar, and the food itself was bland, but got the job done.If overnighting again, I‚Äôd probably go farther afield and try something different, unless they had remodeled. Again, this was super easy, but the room would lead me to try a different, slightly further away property.
response: Dear Valued Guest,Thank you for staying at The Sheraton Miami Airport Hotel & Executive Meeting Center. We appreciate your feed back. We are currently in the process of making changes to our suites. I apologize for your experience while staying with us and thank you for recognizing the service of our staff. We take your feed back seriously and have mad changes to make future guest stays more efficient. We hope we can see you soon soon.Best Regards,Ernesto RiveraHotel Manager
triptype: Trip type: Traveled as a couple
responder: Response from Ernesto R, Manager at Sheraton Miami Airport Hotel & Executive Meeting Center

review: My one night stay was pleasant. However the hotel wasn't up to the normal standards of a Marriot hotel. The good first- my room was just off the elevator but I didn't hear noise from it (other than a few loud kids). The bed was Marriot comfy. The room was generally well appointed. However, The public restroom was not complete. It didn't have soap. It was a little dirty and it had a slide type door lock - very strange for this quality hotel. The plumbing in the room made a very high pitch noise a good portion of the night like it was trying to clear air in the lines. (Fortunately this sound went away by midnight). review: My family and I stayed here for one night prior to leaving out for our cruise. There were twelve of us in three rooms. When arriving, I checked on the status of all of the rooms since everyone else was flying in that afternoon. I was told that three out of four rooms were paid in full and one room the card had been declined. The agent told me that we could fit everyone in three rooms and she could just cancel the fourth room since we wouldn't need it anyways. After checking with the group I went ahead and did so. I was informed that all that was required at this point was the deposits for the rooms. I paid the deposit for the room I wad staying in ($20 on debit card or $50 cash), received the keycards and went to relax. Later, on checking my account I noticed that the hotel had charged my room $122 instead of $20 as discussed. I went down to ask and found out that the room I was in had not actually been paid for. The staff apologized and then stated that they couldn't really do anything. I paid for a room I was told had already been paid in full. I was really disappointed that they did this as I wasn't booking a room and was staying in someone else's. It worked out in the end as the person who had cancelled their room paid me along with two pother persons to cover staying in the hotel room but they should really be more clear and careful with their charges. When we checked out, I was charged for hotel transportation to the pier that I had not asked for. They took the charge off but it was another headache. They served breakfast and it was small but enough to fill us. The rooms were fine and we had no complaints. The beds were comfortable and the business ctr had a printer even though it was two computers with one not working. This hotel is located near a hospital which is good for people coming for procedures. Don't expect to be able to walk places around it though. It's in a seedy area and doesn't feel very safe. The hotel did offer shuttle to a nearby shopping area that was really nice. The driver was very sweet and friendly and accommodating. I wish I could remember her name!
response: We appreciate your candid feedback from your recent stay at the Springhill Suites Miami Downtown/ Medical Center. We are disappointed to learn that you did not enjoy a five-star experience; however your comments allow us to continue to maintain and improve the guest experience. We aim to provide our guests with the highest level of comfort and hope that you will consider giving us another opportunity to exceed your expectations.

hotel: SpringHill Suites New York Manhattan/Times Square South
review: Hmm where do I start. It's not the worst hotel I have ever stayed in but definitely in the low end. If you have very low expectations to your hotel you will probably be fine hence the 2 stars.A bit about the hotel itself. It says "new", but it's actually just renovated which you can clearly tell on the inside. Rooms are VERY small, some of them can barely fit the king size bed. Most bathrooms have a sliding door facing the bed which is a bit uncomfortable. The rooms have a ventilation system besides the AC unit which is quite noisy and cannot be turned off. If you are on the top floor it will sound like a hurricane just outside your door (I brought one of the front desk guys up there and he was even shocked).Elevators are a chapter for themselves, they are very slow and in some rooms you will hear them operate with banging and buzzing sounds.Breakfast is free and decent but basically quantity over quality. Staff are friendly but don't seem to have the power to properly handle and compensate issues.But let's dig into why it was an unpleasant experience for me. I stayed for 5 nights and basically spent the first 24 hours switching rooms until I found one that was tolerable. They kept saying that they were fully booked but somehow found rooms once I insisted. As compensation for my trouble I was given a free drink at the bar which turned out to be only valid for some pre-made punch. Sigh.In summary, the hotel has a good location but is severely lacking in quality. And the high price is in no way justifiable. I would not recommend a stay in this hotel.
response: Dear mortenw386,We want to thank you for choosing to stay with us and for taking the time to post your candid review. review: We came to Seattle to watch a Seahawks game. This was a good location. We arrived early but we couldn't check in until 3 and the game started at 1 so no luck with that. The person at the front desk wasn't very pleasant but maybe it was because they were busy. The hotel is walking distance to the convention centre and many things. The bathroom had a mouldy picture on the wall from the shower steam I assume and the mirror above the sink had water damage so it looked really dirty. The bed was lumpy and not very comfortable and the pillows were terrible. They have a fantastic breakfast in the morning which was a great surprise. The dining room isn't very big but the food was really good. They have coffee 24 hours a day, a bar, newspapers to read and a convenient area to pick up munchies to purchase. It was an OK place.

review: I stayed in Habitat Residence in December 2017. When the check-out, I asked for my money and the receptionist (who was another one because it was during the morning and not the evening as the first day) told me that he couldn't help me because he didn't know anything about it. He asked to his colleague and after verifying it through the Hotel bill, they promised me that they will transfer me the money to my bank account. To this day I'm still waiting for it or at least an asnwer to my emails claiming for a solution.In conclusion, if you go to Habitat Residence, be sure that you pay the exact amount or don't expect to recover the extra sum paid because of their own instructions.

No compensation was suggested when we complained every day, they could have suggested to move our room or drink voucher or something but nothing.My niece asked reception for recommendations on where we could eat, they suggested their restaurant. Then low & behold a chicken & veg comes out which no one had ordered so I took that.The poor barman was run off his feet trying to get our drinks as well as other patrons & running downstairs to bring up our meals as well. Reception should have never recommended we should eat there if they weren‚Äôt staffed properly.Great location but not recommended for families.

review: Stayed at this hotel for 4 nights and it was not a good experience. The only pro is the location, but other than that it is not worth it and this is definitely not a 4 star hotel. What others said about the construction going on is very true - understandable and this is not the hotel‚Äôs fault, BUT the noise from the AC is unbearable. There was another loud noise that I recorded and showed it to the manager ( it happened multiple times a day) when she heard it, she said it was from the AC or the vacuum, then I figured out is came from the mini fridge. The windows are filthy, which ruins the great view of the ES (another pro) Our second day we left at 10 am and returned at 11:00 pm, I only wanted to shower and go to sleep. No towels!! Called the front office and requested towels, after 40‚Äô I decided to use the hand towels. Called again and let them know I was going to sleep to please not send anything...as soon as I fell asleep, they came to deliver the towels ( it was way past midnight). The AC was either freezing or way to hot, so we asked for an extra blanket. They delivered the inside comforter without the cover - it was stained and marked with sharpie. Sheets were cheap and pillows were terrible. Breakfast was so terrible that even when we had it included, we did not use the vouchers (2 out of 4 days). The last morning, the eggs were GREEN and the server said that it was because they were too hot - she did offer to make fresh ones which I declined. Bread and bagels were stale and not edible. No cream cheese or fresh cut fruit. Definitely not a full continental breakfast!!! Not worth the $13 if you need to pay for it. The restaurant is dark and the male server was very rude - the lady was nice. Coffee was terrible (burnt). If you have to pay for it, go somewhere else! Lastly, our shuttle was scheduled for 3pm, I requested a courtesy late check out due to all the problems I had. They let us stay until 1pm, but we were out and it was so hot we needed to take a shower before getting on the plane so we stayed until 2:40 in the room and they charged us $35 - which they advise they would do- I am sure I will get the standard response from management, but what I would like is a partial refund!

hotel: The Bernic Hotel New York City, Tapestry Collection by Hilton
review: To begin with, there is no bellman, so you struggle with your luggage when you arrive by cab. At check in, the front desk staff was uncaring and unconcerned. He told us nothing about the hotel, its dining options, etc. He kept stressing that check in was not until later in the afternoon, which we understood. We had plans to go right to the MET, so that was not a problem. We were told that we would receive a call when our room was ready; however, we never received a call. At checkout, I heard the hotel staff tell people checking in that there was a bar on the top floor of the building. We would have loved to go the bar, had we known about it.Now for the room itself. The room was small. There was no chair in the room and no dresser to put clothes away. We lived out of our suitcases and sat on the bed for 3 days. The room had a step-out balcony, but the door would not unlock; therefore, we could not use it.There was mold in the bathroom. The fan made a loud noise, so we had to turn it off in order to sleep--then the room got very stuffy. There was very poor lighting in the room. There was a reading lamp at each side of the bed; however, the lamp on my side of the bed, did not work. Even though there was two of us on the reservation, we were given a room that had only one robe and a rug on only one side of the bed. In addition, the knob in the shower was very difficult to turn.The cafe, where we received breakfast, was disappointing. They do not serve decaf coffee at breakfast. You have to ask for virtually everything, butter for your toast, jelly for your toast, salt and pepper shaker, and a water refill. Again a very uncaring, unconcerned staff.The positive is that the WiFi is good. The bed was comfortable. Prosecco is served at night--again they don't let you this, we just happened to return to the hotel when it was being served. The location is good, especially if you take a train from Grand Central.

review: This hotel is poor value-for-money for an Santa Monica ocean front hotel. We paid $450 (incl. tax) per night for 3 nights for an ocean view room.The windows are tiny, so you can only stand at the window to look out to the beach. The rooms are small, carpeted and stuffy. The corridor also smells musty and old. The only saving grace is the sea-green tiled bathroom, but still that's tiny.If you insist on an ocean view hotel in Santa Monica, I recommend Hotel Shangri-La, which I stayed at 2 years ago. The ocean view rooms are bigger and have a full view. The bathrooms also also way more comfortable. Pricing was similar to The Georgian.If you just want to stay in Santa Monica, I highly recommend the Palihouse, which I stayed at last week for $473 (incl tax). It's also a historic hotel, but with spacious rooms and fantastic amenities and service.In the same trip, I also stayed at US Grant historic hotel in San Diego, which is absolutely fabulous (huge comfortable room, great service) and only $250 night.I was very disappointed by this hotel. That photo in the banner is not a good example of its rooms. Regret I didn't take photos to show you how small, cramped and old the rooms were.

review: Pretentious staff, old noisy elevator and paper thin walls were the highlight of my trip. Overrated hotel with staff that is disrespectful and condescending. Maids go through your trash and who knows what else. I felt violated and was called a liar. I was told I smoked in my room even though I did not. I was charged $250 for smelling like cigarettes even though I smoked outside. They claimed I should have thrown my butts on the street instead of putting them out and disposing of them in the trash. There are no trash cans or ashtrays outside the hotel, but was told they had them. They must be invisible. They claim other guests smelled smoke but that‚Äôs not possible since I went outside every time I smoked, even at 6 am. I am disgusted by the treatment I received. If people smell smoke in a room that has not been smoked in, they are not being honest or they are delusional. I was told a team of smoke smellers were in the room to investigate and my room smelled so bad they had to shampoo the rug? I have never been treated this way and will be sure to get the word out about the extortion I experienced. Beware of the maids, they will look for any reason to charge you, even go through your trash. Overrated!
response: Dear Dina D,We are so sorry to hear that you did not enjoy your stay with us. The reason for our no smoking policy is to to keep the hotel and guestrooms free of any residual odor as well as not to trouble those who are occupying neighboring rooms, guests with asthma that may be affected, and also the next guests checking into that room which we promote as smoke-free. We value to the safety and comfort of our guests which is why we do have to enforce this policy. After having sent a letter of notification asking as a reminder of the policy, the inaction then lead the property in having to enforce the non-smoking policy acknowledged and signed for at check in. Again, we apologize that this detracted from your stay but truly wish you all the best. Thank you for your visit.

review: Pros:Rooms were clean and had a better view than the hotels I normally stay at in the area. Staff was courteous. Room service was quick and pretty good.Cons:The rooms are dead-silent which is typically a good thing except you can hear a pin drop in the hallway. Turning on the A/C helped drown that out but it made a loud clang every time it would engage and disengage. I measured that interval to be equal to the amount of time it takes to start falling back to sleep.The "modern" elevator was broken during my 4-day stay so all guests and employees had to use the much slower, older one. I took the stairs several times after waiting a while but that in itself was frustrating. There's no stairwell, just separate flights that connect each floor.My last issue is admittedly something that would've required the staff to step outside of their policy but those are the sorts of things that keep people coming back. On the afternoon before my last night, I was able to find an earlier flight so I took it. Once I had confirmation I immediately called the hotel to give up my room. It was escalated to a manager who informed me that I would've had to give notice before noon. That's totally understandable but would've gone a long way towards giving The Georgian a second chance.All things considered, the stay was ok but I'll be returning to my normal accommodations on my next visit to Santa Monica.
response: Dear Les_Vegetables711,Thank you for staying with us and for the nice comments in regard to our location, room service, and courtesy of staff. review: I wanted so to like this Inn. I have stayed at their Beacon St Hotel and found it similar, but this is a much nicer location. It is indeed stylish and the descriptions of all others are accurate insofar as they go. The sheets are high quality and the pillows were lovely. It is close to parking at the Prude ($40/day), and to the mall there, as well as to Newbury St. The area is not really Back Bay --but South Boston.. Still, lots here and the pedestrian parks nearby are terrific.The street is quiet and beautiful. The architectural decor is stunning. WiFi great. Kitchen great.So, what's wrong? Too much--will not come back. With some changes AND a different room, would def come back.1.First, do not book Room 100. The site says it is on the first floor but it is in the basement and is dark, and a bit short on the accouterments. The light was gloomy and the suite smelled musty. The bathroom was unconditionally small, no place to put anything, no sunlight light, and the shower leaks.2. The most distressing characteristic was that it was grossly uncomfortable! Those firm beds everyone mentions, well they are hard as a rock. No joke.3. The single living room chair was hard and uncompromising.4. The plastic chairs at the table/desk were hard, too low, and very uncomfortable.Bad place to eat, impossible to work, no electric plug.5. There was nothing of meaningful size to put anything on--a teeny coffee table and and minor end tables.6. TV requires a PhD (no wait a minute my husband is an MD and I am a PhD) and we followed all directions and could not get it to work. Young man at desk very pleasant--and had to reboot it but it took him 10 mins to get it to work. .7. Breakfast is a misnomer- BAD packaged muffins, some bagels, not much else. Use kitchen and make your own bkfast.For a small hotel, investing in better ma tresses and a few better chairs would markedly improve this comfort. They should not advertise breakfast.I normally stay at the Charles St Inn on Beacon Hil, or the Elliot on Commonwealth/Mass Ave--both are much better, although they are more traditional.I won't be back. You can do better with another Inn or B and B in the area--lovely with enormous boutique potential but management needs to listen about comfort (beds/chairs, and breakfast if nothing else). Truth about Room 100 would have helped make us less disappointed.Sorry--it is lacking badly--and I wish someone had told me. I travel a lot, and this would rate a generous 3 out of 5 from me--it would not take much money to make it a 5.Sorry guys--you need to pay attention to guest comfort--and tell the truth re Room 100!! It is in the basement--and is dark.
response: Dear DC Traveler:Thank you so much for providing feedback on your stay at The Inn.Confusing the distinct and separate neighborhoods of South Boston and the South End is common for travelers new to our City. The Inn is located in the St Botolph Historic Conservation District which, as stated on the St Botolph Neighborhood Association website, boundaries are Huntington Avenue, Copley Place, the Southwest Corridor Park and Massachusetts Avenue. Because of its Back Bay/Prudential location closely bordering the South End, its residents enjoy the benefits of easy access to the many conveniences in both neighborhoods, while nestled in the quiet ambiance of a residential area.Great strides are taken to ensure our descriptions and photographs accurately describe each of our suites. All of our suites boast a Southern exposure. Admittedly lower level units are the first to experience nightfall or the effects of a cloudy day. It is true the ground one bedrooms location in the building is unable to accommodate the floor to ceiling windows found on the first level but we compensate for this by providing a menagerie of lighting options.A typical American continental breakfast is complimentary for our guests and includes coffee, tea, espresso, juice, bagels, muffins, yogurt, fresh fruit, oatmeal, apple sauce and granola bars. Guests who desire a family-style breakfast enjoy the option of our fully accessorized in-suite kitchens or avail themselves of complimentary transport to brunch at our affiliated restaurants; Mistral and Mooo‚Ä¶.We regret that you did not bring your discomfort to our attention during your stay. We would have been happy to provide a pillow top for your mattress or exchange some of our decorative tables if you were looking for more surface area. Guest suggestions in the past have directly resulted in refinements to The Inn at St Botolph experience. Updates have included additional pillow options, bathroom shelving and lighted vanity mirrors to name a few. Our 24/7 support staff is eager to address any guest issues as they arise.The Inn values every guest and appreciates your patronage. We look forward to the opportunity to exceed your expectations on future visits to Boston.Keith BeardsleyDirector of Operations
triptype: Trip type: Traveled as a couple
responder: Response from SheriKlak, Director of Operations at The Inn At St Botolph

review: I'm surprise this property rates so high, the room we were in was poorly lighted, not cleaned well (the carpet was filthy) and any contact that you have with the staff is curt and not too helpful. In the Nespresso Machine we have 1% milk.Once again, I apologize that we did not meet your expectations, and I hope that you will consider us again the next time that you are in Boston.Best Regards,Tom DeSistoGeneral ManagerInn@St.Botolph617-236-8099

review: Recently stayed several days at the Inn at St. Botolph and left feeling a bit disappointed. Let me start off by saying that the rooms are impeccable decorated. I looked through the pictures on this site and my room is pictures and looked exactly as shown -- gorgeous modern furniture and fine linens. But once you get past the appearance there are some basic flaws which make a several day visit at this price point annoying.I will start by listing the negative and needs improvement aspects of the Inn @ St Botolph and then finish the review with the positive aspects.1) Absolutely no parking. I was warned of this by my secretary before arriving but was told it was easy to find. After driving several hours to Boston, I parked in front of the Inn‚Äôs building at 99 Botolph Street to get my several bags of luggage into the hotel and up the elevator to my room. I called the number on the room phone that said house manager (I believe it was room 109) and the gentleman who answered was very cold, uninformed and said that he didn't know where public parking was located and that the Inn Manager Ryan was not available. Very annoying -- so luckily my iPhone had "around me" feature and I was able to find the closest public parking garage about 1.5 blocks away. As this point ‚Äì 30 minutes had passed trying to get the directions and when I looked out the room window to the street there was already a $40 ticket on the windshield of my rental car for parking after 4PM in "Resident Only" meters. I drove down to the public garage and the fee was $23 a day.2) I walked back to the Inn from parking and unpacked by bags to find that there were no counters in the bathroom to place toiletries on. I had to place my items on the nightstand or under the sink. There was also no soap self in the shower which meant shampoo and soap had the rest on the shower floor during the entire visit. Bizarre, but I marked it up to growing pains, as they are a new Inn.3) The security safe on the floor of the small closet was broken and would not stay shut causing the closet door to have issues closing. In such a small room this was creating an issue for me to get passed the bed to the bathroom area. I realized if I placed the ironing board in front of the safe to keep it closed ‚Äì my closet would stay shut.4) I opened my laptop to begin checking emails and look for a nearby restaurant / bar and found I could not connect to the Inn's Wireless Service. I looked around the room and in the drawers for a welcome letter with connection instructions and there were none. Once again, I braved calling the manager on duty and received voicemail (about 7:30 PM). He called back sounding very inconvenienced about 30 minutes later (I felt myself apologizing to him for even calling) and he gave me the pass code for the wireless which I tried but did not work. I wasn‚Äôt about to call back at that point so I emailed the Innkeeper (Ryan) with my issue so he could resolve it. Ryan did not call me on this issue for more than 24 hours -- luckily I had a wireless card that worked close to the window. Once Ryan explained that "pop-up blocker" needed to be turned off ‚Äì it worked fine but then the connection expired later that evening and it did not reconnect again for the entire visit.5) The first morning I woke up and walked into the very nicely appointed kitchenette to make coffee (there is a mini-coffee pot), however I discovered there were no small bags of coffee in the room. The coffee basket required the pre-measured packets so I went out and asked the housekeeper in the hall and she said they do not have coffee available for those machines and I could walk 1/2 a block to the 7-11 for coffee. Not cool and not appropriate when you are obviously trying to attract new, discerning customers.6) Although the sheets on the very plush beds were high thread count (probably Frette) the many pillows were very tall and firm -- to the point I was uncomfortable and ended up sleeping between two of them as I could not get comfortable. There really needs to be a mix of pillows for different styles of sleepers.7) Lastly, the elevator down the hall would "ding" very loudly every time it opened. Even with my room at the end of the hall -- it could be heard throughout the night. I am sure they can lower the volume or even turn off the floor bell since this Inn is very much like a private residence with keypad entries to the rooms instead of keys.The upside of the Inn at Botolph for the price is:1) Location, location, location!2) Beautifully decorated room.3) Security camera for letting visitors in with.4) Walking distance to Prudential Center, shopping and nice cafes / restaurants.5) Very clean -- daily housekeeper.6) You do not feel like you are in a big hotel chain - very intimate (but you do need some service!).7) Frette luxury bathrobes and plush white towels in bathroom.8) Rain style showerhead in bathroom.9) Windows open fully to allow breeze into room and gives a nice street view.10) Fully stocked kitchen (cups, plates, wine glasses, etc.) and refrigerator has an icemaker.I think once the Inn at 99 Botolph work through the growing pains of being new it will become a truly wonderful place to stay. They need work on refining the guest service dramatically and have the house manager (or someone) greet guests during basic Inn hours. If guests arrive late there should be a welcome letter or phone call from the Innkeeper explaining wireless, nearby public parking, cool places to eat and where to get coffee / breakfast the next morning‚Ä¶ things that you would do if a guest was staying in your home.I hope this review was useful and best regards.Experienced Business and Leisure Traveler
response: Dear Sir:Your recent review of The Inn @ St. Botolph on TripAdvisor caught my attention. I truly appreciate your feedback and want to assure you that although your experience was atypical, we are taking appropriate steps to see that it remains so.We appreciate you taking into consideration the fact that we just opened and have some growing pains to overcome. In our effort to create an affordable luxury experience, The Inn @ St. Botolph has limited certain services such as the availability of a valet and parking. While this fact already appears on all confirmations, we are making it more visible and will be providing parking recommendations on our website and in the rooms. We realize that you had difficulty and will be more than happy to cover the cost of your parking ticket if you provide us with a receipt.Each room at The Inn @ St. Botolph is unique, and most are equipped with bathroom shelf space. Unfortunately the delivery of the shower shelving was delayed until after our opening, so guests staying in early November did not have the opportunity to use them. In response to your other suggestions, we are currently working with our designer to provide additional shelf space near the bathroom sink and are completing an in-room directory which will clearly explain how to use our free hard-wired and wireless internet along with a quick reference for trouble shooting.We will soon expand our pillow selection and begin including complimentary coffee packets in each room for those guests who do not wish to avail themselves of the coffee, espresso and cappuccino offered with continental breakfast daily in our lounge. The elevator ring has already been addressed and the in room safes have instructions so guests can utilize them with ease.Lastly and most significantly, there is no excuse for making a guest feel uncomfortable under any circumstance. There is no other remedy than to upgrade our service standards and reinvigorate our staff. Trust that each member of our small but dedicated staff has seen your comments and has been reminded of the role they play in guaranteeing the comfort of our guests.I hope that you will take my assurances to heart and will consider returning to The Inn @ St. Botolph.Kindest Regards,Keith BeardsleyDirector of Operations
responder: Response from innatstbtolph, Director of Operations at The Inn At St Botolph

review: This place should NOT be considered a hotel by any standard. It is an INN and has even fewer of the amenities of a beach town b & b. The suite that I'm in has tiny rooms and doll house furniture. It is also on the fourth floor so there is next-to-no water pressure to the lovely rain forest shower head. The bathoom is also child-sized and the fancy rack to hold soaps is almost falling off the wall.The minimal service policy does nothing to benefit the environment but I'm sure it helps the bottom line. If you want to spend $300-400/night and have a great travel experience, stay at the big sister of this place, XV Beacon. Much better location, service. And at least there's a feeling of safety rather than the 'down home' feeling offered here in this sometimes sketchy marginal neighborhood.
response: Dear Jjohnzi,The Inn At St Botolph offers a unique approach to hospitality. We pride ourselves on providing an exceptional experience unlike any other hotel.Our sister hotel, XV Beacon, is a four star property with which we are pleased to share a similar design, look and feel. While we realize that not everyone has the same taste in design and architecture, we are honored to have our interiors created by the same Hall of Fame Designer, Celeste Cooper.Every suite is far more spacious than an ordinary hotel room. Each offers a sitting area, table for dining or work, and a kitchenette with a full size refrigerator. Our selection of custom designed furniture includes king or queen four poster beds, full length sofas, wing back chairs and original artwork. All units feature 42‚Äù HD TV‚Äôs and one and two bedroom suites boast a gas fireplace.The Inn is centrally located near Copley Square, between Boston‚Äôs most desirable neighborhoods: the Back Bay and South End. Our location allows guests to reside in a historic brownstone on a quiet residential street one block from Boston‚Äôs finest dining, shopping and attractions.Complimentary amenities include high tech features such as wireless and high speed internet, video intercom systems, national calling and extended satellite service. Guests enjoy our state of the art keyless entry system, fitness center, daily continental breakfast and preferred pricing at our acclaimed restaurants. Our all inclusive price and innovative reservation procedures eliminate the hassles of check-in and check-out and makes certain there are no surprises on your bill!Our team works very hard to clarify how we are unique. review: I usually do not write reviews, but I needed to write one about this place. I have not had the time, and frankly has been slipping my mind. I stayed here September 12-15. Upon check-in I was told I needed to pay a "resort fee" of $40 per night. This hotel doesn't have room service, let alone resort amenities. I said this to the girl checking me in. She rolled her eyes and puckered her lips at me like a child. She had no name tag. Then, she told me the king room was not available and would I mind staying in a double bed room...which I said yes because I was with my young daughter and thought it would be better that way. The room was beyond dirty. My daughter suffers from allergies and ended up getting asthma. The bathroom had mold in the tub, on the walls, and the toilet ran all night. The windows looked like they had not been cleaned in years, so there goes the view. The mattress looked like they had a bed-bug problem at some point. We wore shoes at all times in the room because the floor smelled and felt like there was salt poured all over it. It was the worst stay I have EVER had. DO NOT STAY HERE!!! Pay the extra and stay at the Sheraton across the street. This hotel is not worth a penny. The girl who checked me in should never have the pleasure of being employed anywhere. She was rude and nasty. A woman came over to ask her a question, and because she had an accent, she rolled her eyes, and called someone else over to say she couldn't understand her. I understood her perfectly. I would tell her name but again, she had no name tag. I was born and raised in NYC and this was not typical "NYC rudeness", this girl should not work anywhere with that kind of attitude.

review: This was my second stay here and it was lovely to be back. The hotel is a small hotel on 8th Street, beautifully refurbished from an old rooming house, so the rooms are correspondingly small. But it has a certain vibe; it is well furnished in the main areas, and the rooms are well designed. In-room space can be an issue. The double bed (possibly queen) naturally dominates the room, with no real space around it, so luggage has to be stowed under the bed (not always possible with large suitcases) The wardrobe and mini-bar arrangement is adequate, but a challenge if you have a longer stay and lots of clothes. That said, the linens and towels are first class, and the television is a good size. There is a coffee bar within the main lobby, but no room service. We were there as guests of our family, so did not spend a lot of time in the hotel. However, we stayed 'home' on a couple of evenings and enjoyed dinner from a local deli. There are lots of good places to eat close by, and a great coffee shop next door - Lena's. Staff are helpful and friendly, with the Bell Captain (Dimarcus) especially good to meet and he is both helpful and welcoming. The restaurant staff were okay but on one occasion (breakfast) our Server was surly and that was a disappointment. Overall the hotel is lovely, but boutique hotel usually means small hotel, so bear that in mind.

hotel: The Maxwell Hotel - A Staypineapple Hotel
review: If you're just interested in the short review, here goes. If you're 24 or younger, or you are 40 and identify as 24 or younger as evident by the raucous 40th birthday celebration taking place in the lobby, this is the hotel for you. If not, read on...If I could just rate the woman who checked us in at the front desk, I'd rate her five stars all the way. Competent, polite and understanding; she certainly took her job seriously and I appreciated that. She quickly checked us in after a long drive from San Juan Island and by looking at our Toyota 4Runner with a Thule box on top she promptly gave us access to the available parking spot outside of the garage realizing that we'd never make the low clearance of the parking garage.You read right, if you have a SUV, truck or perhaps a lifted Subaru Outback (we're from Portland, Oregon and it's a thing here) with a travel box on top, forget about parking the the garage, the clearance is far too low. More on parking later in the review.Once parked, it was time to finally unload and we were hoping...unwind. We unpacked the car and headed to our room on the fourth floor. The elevators are unbelievably slow and there are only two. One of which broke down during our stay leaving only one functioning elevator for the entire hotel. Murphy's Law I suppose.You have to insert your key card to access your floor. I'm not sure if this is common for all of the Pineapple hotels, or just The Maxwell Hotel. Either way, I am juggling bags, kids and now fumbling for my room key to just get to my floor.Finally, I slam the key in slot and hit the number 4 for the fourth floor. Once the elevator doors open, I'm greeted by what would appear to be circus colors. Queue the clowns! But, what's that smell?Oh, that's the folks in room 420 celebrating their stay with a nice long toke. No smoking or vaping allowed at The Maxwell Hotel you say? Apparently that rule applies to every room BUT room 420. The entire hall reeked of marijuana. Now before you get upset and judge us as some marijuana prudes, we're from Portland and if Oregon can do one thing right, it's grow and smoke weed. However, the last thing I want to to do is explain to my children the origin of 4:20 during my stay in a rather expensive hotel.Thank God, our room did not smell of pot, but the wallpaper on the walls was anything but relaxing. You're presented two duvets per queen bed and you're scratching your head as to what you're supposed to do. Luckily, they realize this is not normal and provide you with some Ikea-inspired hieroglyphs on how to utilize your "European" duvets. Needless to say, the same amount of cursing associated with assembling your Ikea entertainment center commenced.We registered our kids, so I'm not sure if they placed the $25.00 stuffed dog because of that, or if they do it for every room, but there was a stuffed dog that our daughter was dead set on getting.Spoiler alert; it wasn't worth $25.00 and she didn't get it. Parent win!Did I mention that everything in this room is for sale? Yep, you can buy the coffee mug for $25.00, you can buy a mystery munchie box of mystery snacks for $25.00; no, you don't know what's in it, but if you're a gambler you can find out for just $25.00! You can buy branded dog bowls and more! For just $150.00 you can be a Stay Pineapple walking billboard...wonderful!There is branding absolutely everywhere! Just about every surface has a pineapple plastered on it. The glasses have pineapples, the towels have pineapples, the pillows have pineapples, the water has pineapples, everything has pineapples. Not to mention the immature innuendo that is repeated everywhere. You're Do Not Disturb door tag says "I'm naked" and the pillows are embroidered with "Sleep With Me." We're just a pole away from from feeling like we're sleeping in a strip club.That's not a knock against the Maxwell Hotel, but rather the Pineapple Hotel chain.Finally, we're settled. Our "high-riding" vehicle parked, our European-style beds made and the T.V on. Now we're hungry!Luckily McMinneman's is located just across the street, unless you're interested in overpriced sundries at the hotel. From there we were able to wear out the kids with a walk past the Space Needle.A big positive of The Maxwell Hotel; location. You can't beat this location if you're touring Seattle. Close to the Space Needle, Key Arena and the International Fountain, you can really see quite a bit with just a short walk.Our kids wanted to hit the pool...because they're kids...This pool is barely big enough for your grandma! One family at a time. Luckily from our room, we had direct view of the pool through the windows and unfortunately it would seem that families must be lining up for the pool since it was full from 6:30pm - 10:00pm! Sorry kids, no pool for you. You can always take a warm bath; wait, there's no bathtub? Damn.The shower blows water all over the floor because it doesn't have a door or a curtain. I know that when you're completely drunk, this shower is easy access, but not all of us are functioning alcoholics and like to keep the floor dry to avoid unnecessary falls.Speaking of the shower, it almost seems like the hot water is metered. It can be piping hot and after 10 - 15 minutes it becomes ice cold until you crank the the handle to full hot. After an audible thud it then scalds you and you have to readjust it for another 10 - 15 minutes of a hot shower. I can't say it's actually metered, or if it was our room or perhaps the plumbing is old?It's about 10:00pm, time for bed. You'll learn that the TV's in this place will shut themselves off! Yes, that's right, they have built in timers; not a sleep timer, but an actual timer. You have to tell it that you're still watching or it will turn off. Good luck finding the remote when it's pitch black in your room!Check out time.Remember that parking situation? For that limited clearance parking you're paying $37.00 a day PLUS applicable taxes! So you're paying around $50.00 a day to park your car here. Did they tell me when I checked in? No. The snarky young man at the desk told me that there was a sign. He wasn't lying, there IS a sign, but really? $37.00 a night PLUS taxes? Come on. I am already paying nearly $200 a night for this place, you can't comp me some parking in YOUR garage?When we questioned the young man, he basically told us "oh well, pay up." According to hotels.com we owed $191.00 for our stay, we ended spending over $250.00!We've stayed in very high-end hotels and none of them were like this. If you're into fake crystal everywhere, mirrors with stickers, circus colors and the stench of weed, this is the hotel for you!
response: Dear clee109,Thank you so much for taking the time to write a review regarding your recent stay with us. I am so sorry you did not enjoy your stay. It is important to us that our guests experience a comfortable, fun stay with great service! We apologize for the annoyance caused from a guest smoking. This is something we do not allow, for the comfort of all our guests we do our best to enforce our 100% smoke free of any kind policy. I have shared your comments with our entire team, to ensure we strive to provide great service and to maintain our rooms quality. I am sorry we were not the right fit for your travel. I appreciate you taking the time to keep us informed. It is with suggestions and input from our guests that allow us to strive for great, so thank you!Safe Travels,Jamie Randall

review: I can't understand how anyone can say this hotel is quiet. We stayed in a corner room on the 6th floor. The traffic noise, even with the windows tightly closed is unreal. When the buses (and there are many) stop and go at the traffic light, they sound like a train! The old style fan/airconditioner underneath the window is also noisy and rather than masking the noise, lets the street noise below in. We never heard any noise from neighboring guests but workers were renovating from 11-3 am. It sounded to us like it was coming from the room above - drilling, sawing, hammering. Wearing earplugs didn't help. We phoned the front desk twice and were told different stories. One said it was from the kitchen -6 floors down- we still find it hard to believe. They gave us a free breakfast to compensate us, but our holiday was ruined. Why do they have to renovate at night? I wasn't impressed with its cleanliness either since we found coins laying on the carpet. The sheer curtain was torn, and the room needs updating. The bathroom was lovely and clean. The separate shower and toilet was great. For the price we paid, we'd never stay there again and don't recommend it. There's lots of choice nearby.
response: Thank you for taking the time to write about your recent experience at the Paramount Hotel. We really value your feedback. I know this review response will not change your experience but I hope that you can feel confident that we heard your concerns and are definitely doing something about them.
triptype: Trip type: Traveled as a couple

review: Be warned - bad customer service experienceI will start by pointing out my last five reviews of businesses (across platforms) have been 5 stars. I like to give positive feedback. my experience with this hotel was so bad I have to share it as a warning.I booked a room online assuming that my State was still on the Covid19 test free list. I accept it was primarily my responsibility to check. It is not the point of this bad review.I checked the morning I was to travel to Boston, only to read I actually needed a test (72 hours). I called to hotel to get clarification. I was told by the manager (who picked up the call) that I needed the test. I said it would have helped it is was clearer when booking. She stated ‚Äúeverybody knows about the testing requirements‚Äù. This is the first insulting statement. I did not know that MA used a rolling 5% infection rate website and that my State had be in and out of that list twice over the last few weeks. I imagine some people reading this were also not aware of this, in cannot imagine everybody was aware. I am not convinced this manager was aware, and if she was it might have been better to offer sympathy and explain it. That was the first insult. She went on to say that I could ‚Äúcancel my stay with zero refund‚Äù. Which is the second and deliberately rude insult. What a welcome. I asked to speak to an owner which she refused saying she is the manager. Third insult.Customer Service is about the way you do things. I am sorry sir, let me see what I can do etc etc. No, I was insulted three times and then they took my $145. No split ,no credit, just rudeness. I have had relatives stay at this hotel once, they will never again. I will never stay there. My hope is that I convince one person to turn to one of the better hotels in Boston if you value a considerate customer service expeince.I am "out" $145 and 'in" three insults. A two for one customer exerience. You have been warned.
response: Hi 76travelxj,I sincerely apologize for the miscommunication. Could you please directly reach out to me so that I can get your reservation details and do my absolute best to make things right.Elaine KuoFront Desk/HR Managerelaine@theverbhotel.com508-287-8311

review: I am a new poster on Trip Advisor but do plan all my trips according to the information I find on T.A.I am writing this post today because for the first time my experience at a recommended hotel did not live up to the hype. I have allot of good things to say about the WSI but also allot of negatives. I'll start with the negatives.Negatives:-Hotel offered very poor water pressure (not a major concern)-Hotel room we were provided with offered no mini-fridge-Hotel staff states that air conditioning unit can not be turned down past 70 degrees****MOST IMPORTANTLY****-Hotel room stunk. I stood on the 6th floor and the hotel stunk of mold or moist air. The moisture was so bad that the linens on the bed felt moist at all times (quite difficult to sleep on a bed that is moist and a room that is 72 degrees) My partner and I are very easy going so rather than complain dealt with the situation.Positives:-Great location-Cheap Rates-Nice bed/linens-Clean room-Clean HotelThats really my review of the Wall Street Inn in a nutshell. I would have given the hotel great reviews if the humidity/water vapor/moisture problem was under control. The other issues I listed as negatives were not a problem; after all who cares about a mini fridge and 70 degrees is cool enough for most.Unfortunately, and much to our displeasure and disappointment was the moist rooms. The entire floor stunk and a few other posters have made note of humidifiers (I did not see any). The entire time I was there I thought to myself, "how come they didnt give me another room?" because the hotel seemed empty (it was the weekend). The hotel didn't take action to inform us of the 'situation' or take any 'visible' steps to resolve the smell. Oh and as a side note the windows in our 'corner' room had the handles removed so opening the windows was impossible.We did enjoy the trip to the city. I personally would not give the WSI another opportunity. I'd rather have stayed at a chain (and that is very unlike me). If your downtown or in NYC in general you will probably spend very little time in your room so finding a place with a dry comfortable bed and a room with an AC you can control is important to me... especially when its 100 degrees outside.
response: Dear Guest,Thank you for taking the time to write about your experience with us. First of all, please allow us to extend our deepest regrets that we did not live to your expectations; we will try harder in the future. In addressing your concerns we would like to share that our property is in a historic building build in the 1920's. It was certainly not build according to 21-century code regarding insulation and cooling and we are aware of the problems that humidity causes during the summer months. We tried to correct the insulation problem with our gut renovation of this landmark buliding taking additional measures running de-humidifiers during the day. Should any of our guests however reports discomfort we are glad to change the room immediately.As to regards to your other concerns we would like to point that all rooms offer mini fridge/ cooler located in the armoire under the TV. During the dates of your stay ConEd was reducng power to many customers due to the heat wave and has requested that all users in the city reduce use of power to avoid blackouts/brownouts.Once again we appologize for the inconveniences caused and sincerely hope that you would give us another try in the future.
triptype: Trip type: Traveled as a couple
responder: Response from WallStreetInn, General Manager at The Wall Street Inn

review: My husband and I were very excited to be staying here because it is in the heart of the historic area and is 1 block from Fraunces Tavern. We had a corner king on the top (7 th) floor. Scaffolding covered the inn so the view wasn‚Äôt much but that‚Äôs ok. The bed was comfortable, the housekeeper very friendly as was the woman tending the breakfast area.The front desk staff, however, is another matter entirely. The two we were in contact with were apathetic bordering on rude. I did not see either crack a smile and we were there four days. There was no‚ÄùGood morning‚Äù, Hello, or ‚ÄúThank you for staying with us‚Äù. When we checked out, the woman did not even try to hide her annoyance. My husband asked the gentleman if there were any good cigar stores nearby. He said there used to be but it was closed. My husband did a google search then and found a cigar store about five minutes walk.We were interested in getting a taxi to take us to either the airport or Penn station and my husband asked if they could arrange it. He was told essentially he could do it (himself).The room and location was great and we would love to say we will be back. We will not. I expect at least an attempt to provide customer service. Neither employee would last long in a hotel where we live.
response: Dear Stephanie,Thank you for sharing your impressions from a recent stay with us. We are glad that you liked our location and regret to learn that you felt mistreated in any way. We understand that it is a personal perception; we will try harder in the future.The cigar store you refer to has reopened at a nearby location; we just learned the fact and were not aware of it during your visit. review: The Wall Street Inn was expensive for me, and I wanted to like it because of its pretty lobby, attractive room with three phones (honest), the NY Times outside my door in the morning, and complimentary breakfast. But there was no chain on the door, and I had trouble locking it when I left, so I never felt sure it was locked. I'd have given a lot for an ordinary chain. A roaring noise contributed to keeping me up most of the night--possibly an air conditioner in the hall, I'm not sure. I turned off the heating and cooling system in the room but that didn't help. The complimentary breakfast was inedible: fluffy, tasteless bagels and coffee that came from a container that must have once held hazelnut coffee. I don't usually write reviews but these problems were so bad and so specific that I felt I must.

review: I stayed at The Willows for two nights while I helped my son move. The hotel is in an older building and very nice looking. Positives were the price and location. The snacks and the drinks in the honor bar were very reasonably priced. However, there were a whole bunch of other things that led me to drop my rating. First off there was no continental breakfast, despite it being advertised on the website. This very well could have been because of the Covid protocols, but then it should be mentioned on the website. The room was spacious, but the bathroom was not. The toilet sits in a recessed area, and was very snug. There was a small pedestal sink with a narrow shelf above it to place toiletries. There was also a very small cabinet, but that also had towels in it. The shower had very poor pressure, and the tub floor was curved so my ankles and knees hurt after being in there. There soaps, lotions and shampoos were in pump containers, which is good, however there were collars around the pumps so you had to pump excessively to get a fair amount of shower soap. Minor annoyances: The room was long but not very deep. The television was fixed to the wall so you couldn't swivel it for better viewing from an angle. The television had a program guide on one channel, and there was also a two sided channel guide. None of these actually matched the channels programmed into the television in the room. There was not pen to mark items on the honor bar. Lots of little things, plus an uncomfortable bathroom means I won't be returning.Bed rating - comfortable if you like soft beds.
response: Thank you for your review and for staying with us recently. We appreciate your feedback
responder: Response from Juan M, Manager at The Willows

review: Room 110Friday night... girls nite, golden girls nite, first time in Miami not in a resort or boutique hotel on South Beach. But just look at this place, I am a fan of atomic age hotels and roadside hotel/motels. One day I hope to stay a nite at the Madonna Inn or even the tee-pee hotels. I was thrilled, free parking, look at that pool, cute a** rooms. I love mid century modern kitch as much as the next 40yr old. I was not even swayed by the fact there was a humidifier or a loud air conditioner... finally something to drown out my snoring!! Went to bed early, pool music barely audible. Bed so ultra sinkable we were rendered immobile. That is until I looked over at the white plastic alarm clock and thought is that what I think it is. Nah, turning my head away from the alarm clock glow. OH NO then I felt it in my hair. ACK leaping out of bed waking my partner, (after all this was my birthday trip) in this pristine white bed in a spotless room stood a giant palmetto bug on my pillow. I said GET IT (at home I am the one to get it) she drags the pillow off the bed ever so slowly. The bug gallantly riding on the pillow as if floating on a cloud. She says i got it.. i say thats not getting it, then in her sleepy ultimate wisdom she puts the fluffy bath robe over it, STILL NOT GOT IT, i drag the robe covered roach riding pillow to the room door to put him outside and it scuttered under the base board in the bathroom. All in all it was a pretty nice stay at this beautifully renovated mid mod hotel in Miami for my birthday! Even if I woke up to a palmetto bug in my hair in the middle of the night üåô Went for a morning swim and as lovely as the pool was it couldn't shake the thoughts of the roach in my hair. I live in Florida, I have lived in Florida for almost 30 years I understand there will be bugs. First hidden charge - that is a front desk training issue.Secondly, when we arrived to the room, while it was small, that was expected given the capsule hotel design. The room did optimize the space and I was a fan of the bed. However, we had no hot water and had to call for facilities to come by at midnight - I had called ahead and informed the property that we would be arriving late and they should have ensured the room was functioning before checking us in.Other issues that popped up during the stay - no curtain between the bathroom and the bedroom even though the tracks were on the ceiling. Leaking sink - we ended up stuffing towels underneath it. Mirror at the bathroom had electrical issues as it wouldn't turn on unless you tapped it a few times and finally the towel rack heater was not working and I had called to have this fixed and it never was looked at. Oh and we did not have a TV remote in the room and had to call three times for it to be sent up. Heads up: they charge you for luggage storage as well - which is usually a complimentary service for most full-service hotels.Overall, since we were out most of the day and stayed a short time, I didn't really care for the tits and tats, but they kept adding up which was annoying.
